title: Malta’s approach to tackling traffic congestion questioned in new EU report
subtitle: European Semester Report praises Malta's economy, flags broader concerns.
content: An EU report has questioned Malta’s carrot-not-stick approach to tackling traffic congestion, arguing that incentive-based measures have been “largely ineffective”. The European Semester Report, which traces Malta’s progress across a range of sectors, was presented to MCESD on Wednesday. The report points to a raft of measures unveiled earlier this year, singling out proposals to offer cash incentives to people willing to give up their cars or driving licences, or those willing to switch to small motorcycles. These measures “still favour rewards over sanctions,” the report says. Meanwhile, promises to create new parking facilities “will further encourage car use, leading to increased congestion”. The report notes that “measures to tackle congestion by disincentivising the use of private cars…are not foreseen”. “Policies in place to address traffic congestion have been predominately incentive-based and largely ineffective,” the report says. Its authors also say that measures to improve public road transport and alternative modes of mobility “seem to be systematically lacking,” with a 2024 ban on rental e-scooters further reducing options for alternative mobility. Government figures say the proposals unveiled earlier in the year are short-term, voluntary initiatives intended to encourage a cultural shift towards alternative modes of transport, with longer-term measures (including a mass transit system) set to follow. Meanwhile, recently announced plans to extend Malta’s sea transport network have broadly met with public approval. The report explores several other areas of Malta’s social and economic development, heaping praise on the country’s economic performance but flagging several broader concerns. Economic growth is expected to continue, with Malta’s low unemployment figures likely to remain stable. Meanwhile, the country’s deficit is likely to dip at a faster rate than expected, with the country’s debt-to-GDP ratio well within the EU’s recommended margins. However, Malta remains highly dependent on fossil fuels, with one of the lowest rates of renewable energy uptake across the EU. Malta’s blanket energy subsidies “hinder electrification” and should be phased out in favour of further investment in green investments and strengthening grid capacity, the report says. Meanwhile, poverty is rising among specific groups, including children, non-EU nationals, and older adults. Policy measures to address poverty among vulnerable groups have yet to yield results, the report suggests. And Malta still faces long-standing problems of court delays and skills shortages, with “systemic shortcomings” in Malta’s educational system resulting in “persistently insufficient basic skills,” as well as low enrolment of tertiary students in STEM subjects. Positive report but several 'areas for improvement': MCESD In a statement, MCESD said the report highlights “a strong and dynamic Maltese economy but points to areas requiring improvement”. The Council outlined the call for Malta to invest more in research and development, as well as to cut transport emissions and tackle traffic congestion. Meanwhile, Finance Minister Clyde Caruana welcomed the report, describing it as “a moment of satisfaction but also of motivation”. “We must continue working together to invest in crucial areas such as research, innovation, and training, and create a sustainable and inclusive economy for all,” he said.
top_image_caption: Malta hopes to cut traffic congestion through an incentive-based approach. File photo: Matthew Mirabelli

title: Motorcyclist grievously injured in Msida collision
subtitle: The accident happened on Wednesday evening
content: A motorcyclist was grievously injured in a traffic accident in Msida on Wednesday evening. The collision occurred at around 6:30 p.m. on Triq Mikiel Anton Vassalli and involved a Smart car driven by a 40-year-old Italian woman residing in Mosta, and a Honda WW125 motorcycle ridden by a 45-year-old man from Ħamrun. The motorcyclist was taken to Mater Dei Hospital by ambulance, where he was certified to have sustained grievous injuries. Police investigations are ongoing.

title: Tourist dies after falling off hotel balcony in St Julian's
subtitle: The British man was certified dead on site
content: Updated 4.22pm A British tourist died in the early hours of Friday after falling off the balcony of his hotel in St Julian's. Police said preliminary investigations indicated that the 25-year-old man fell off the balcony of the hotel on Triq Spinola at around 4.15am. A medical team was called but the man was pronounced dead on the scene. Magistrate Philip Galea Farrugia is leading the inquiry, assisted by several experts as police investigations continue. Times of Malta has confirmed that the fatal incident happened at the Cavalieri Art Hotel and that the man fell off a balcony facing Triq Spinola, though no other details were available at the time of publication.  The police told Times of Malta that the road was temporarily closed for traffic earlier on Friday morning but once the body was taken away, the road was reopened. By 9am on Friday morning, the hotel appeared to be operating as usual with nothing to suggest the tragic events of the night before. Welsh news outlet Newyddion S4C reported Friday afternoon that the deceased tourist was a Welsh man from Gwynedd.

title: Public invited to propose tech solutions for Malta’s traffic problems
subtitle: Grants of up to €50,000 made available through new expression of interest
content: Individuals, SMEs and startups have been offered up to €50,000 to propose innovative digital solutions to help manage Maltese traffic. The expression of interest, announced by the Transport Ministry on Saturday, is open to submissions from anyone who believes they have an idea that could significantly improve the situation on local roads. Ideas can range from traffic management systems to digital solutions to help connect people to vacant parking spots. Individuals who submit ideas can receive grants of up to €20,000 while startups, SMEs and other companies are eligible for grants of up to €50,000. Apart from grants, successful applicants will receive mentoring, access to official data and infrastructure and help to bring their ideas to fruition. Proposals can be submitted until September 30 and more information is available online. Transport Minister Chris Bonett urged people to take part in the initiative. “The government is willing to invest in digital projects to improve road commuting nationwide,” he said. Transport Malta CEO Kurt Farrugia echoed that. “We are opening our doors to any opportunities that might improve Malta’s mobility. Transport Malta is committed to providing a real platform to those with innovative ideas,” Farrugia said. The expression of interest was announced during a visit the minister paid to World Pro Racing, which is using renders of local roads and sites on various advanced simulators.
top_image_caption: A driving simulator at World Pro Racing. Photo: Transport Ministry

title: Watch: Alleged Bidnija killer rams car in road rage incident in January
subtitle: Video shows him driving large water tanker truck straight into a car in St Paul's Bay
content: A man accused of the recent Bidnija murder was at the wheel of a truck that appeared to have deliberately ploughed into a vehicle in an incident last January, according to footage obtained by Times of Malta. The alleged road rage incident shows the large vehicle driving straight into the car on the road as a man is seen trying to close the back passenger door. Mohamed Hamdan was later identified as the driver of the truck. The incident happened on January 20 on Triq it-Turisti in St Paul’s Bay. Hamdan, 46, who has a history of crime, stands accused of killing Jean Paul Busuttil following a collision between the two on a country lane in Bidnija early on June 29. He is pleading not guilty to all charges.  Surveyors’ reports seen by Times of Malta detail the extensive damage sustained by the car of the victim, who is still chasing his money. One of the reports states that the car sustained “very extensive damages on the left side panels, rear and right front”. The collision also caused the left side airbags to deploy. The left side panels were pushed onto the passenger’s compartment. The rear extensive damage affected the tailgate, rear panel, tow bar, rear trim and rear right wing. It estimated the total repair costs at €13,759. The surveyor appointed by the insurance estimated the repair works at €15,658. Questions have been sent to the police about the case. Times of Malta understands that they are expected to take action.
top_image_caption: A screengrab of the moment the truck is driven into the car.

title: Motorcyclist left with serious injuries after traffic accident in Marsaxlokk
subtitle: The incident happened on Melqart Street at around 11am
content: A motorcyclist was left with serious injuries Monday after a traffic accident in Marsaxlokk. Initial investigations suggest a collision occurred between a Kymco motorbike driven by a 35-year-old French national and a 30-year-old Ħaż-Żabbar resident on Melqart Street at around 11am. The French national was treated at the scene before being taken to Mater Dei Hospital, where his injuries were certified as serious. Investigations are ongoing.

title: Motorist fined €4,000 after grievously injuring woman using pelican crossing
subtitle: Witness describes seeing the accused's car approach at 'abnormal' speed
content: A motorist has been fined €4,000 after being found guilty of grievously injuring a pedestrian after he crashed into a car waiting at a pelican crossing, sending it smashing into a woman crossing the road. St Paul’s Bay resident Jithu James, 32, was accused of driving a vehicle in a dangerous, negligent and reckless manner and grievously injuring a pedestrian in an incident that occurred in October 2023. A motorist who was on his way home from work at the time of incident, explained he had been waiting for pedestrians to cross a pelican crossing on December 13 Road when he saw a vehicle being driven at an “abnormal” speed. The speeding vehicle crashed into the witness’ car, which in turn hit a pedestrian using the crossing. The witness exited his vehicle, called the emergency services and went to assist a woman who was lying on the ground. In his testimony, he recalled that she was not in a “good” state. Under cross-examination he confirmed he had stopped but not pulled up his handbrake. He also confirmed he had not been charged in connection with the incident. Another witness, who had been using the crossing at the time of the incident, explained he had been crossing the road with his dog, with a woman walking next to him. Two cars had been waiting for pedestrians to finish using the crossing, he recalled, when a third car crashed into one of the stationary cars. He added that his dog lost a tooth in the crash. The man remained with the woman until the ambulance came. The court in its considerations held that James failed to maintain a proper lookout while driving, especially when approaching a pedestrian crossing. The man was fined €4,000 and had 10 points knocked off his licence. He was disqualified from holding a driving licence for three months. Magistrate Yana Micallef Stafrace presided.
top_image_caption: The woman was hit while using a pelican crossing. Photo: Shutterstock.

title: Teenager critically injured in Balluta Bay jet ski crash
subtitle: 18-year-old Albanian national brought to shore by dinghy, police say
content: A teenager was critically injured in a crash between two jet skis in Baluta Bay on Friday afternoon, police said in a statement on Saturday. The 18-year-old Albanian national was rescued at sea, placed in a dinghy and taken to shore before being rushed to Mater Dei Hospital by ambulance. He was hurt when a jet ski he was riding was involved in a collision with another at around 4.30pm in the bay. Police said they have launched an investigation into the incident. title: Teen injured in jet‑ski crash at Balluta Bay
content:
An 18‑year‑old Albanian man is in hospital with serious injuries following a collision between two jet skis in Balluta Bay on Friday afternoon.
According to police, the crash occurred at about 4.30 p.m. when the craft struck each other in the popular St Julians bathing area.
The injured rider was taken ashore by dinghy and transferred by ambulance to Mater Dei Hospital, where doctors certified his condition as serious.

title: Teen cyclist in critical condition after Rabat crash
content:
A 16-year-old boy from Mtarfa is in critical condition following a bicycle accident that occurred around 12:30 p.m. yesterday on Triq il-Buqana, Rabat.
Initial investigations revealed that the teenager lost control of his bicycle and collided with a wall.
Emergency responders provided immediate medical assistance at the scene before rushing him to Mater Dei Hospital by ambulance.
Doctors later confirmed that the boy suffered serious injuries and is currently at risk of dying.
Magistrate Dr Antoine Agius Bonnici LL.D. has ordered an inquiry, while police investigations into the incident are still underway.

title: Rider injured in hit-and-run is told tunnel cameras don’t work
subtitle: He wants to find out who hit him 'to avoid future accidents' and a refund for damages incurred
content: A scooter rider injured in a hit-and-run crash in the Regional Road tunnels earlier this month is struggling to track down the driver, after being told that none of the tunnel cameras work. Giuseppe Di Dio, a 22-year-old Sicilian who works as a DJ and event organiser, was riding his Vespa 300 on July 2 at around 12.30pm when he was hit. As he entered the tunnel heading towards Swieqi, he says a van crossed into his lane, cut him off and crashed into him, knocking him off his Vespa. “I feel super lucky to tell the story. It hurt a lot. When I was on the floor, I could feel my burns,” he told Times of Malta. Shocked by the impact, Di Dio said he could not identify the van but recalled opening his eyes to see the driver standing over him. According to Di Dio, the man looked South Asian and was wearing a blue shirt. He believes he was driving a delivery van but is unsure which company the van belonged to. “He came over, checked I was alive, told me nothing and rushed off,” he said. “I know if I saw him, I would recognise him.” Thankfully, other drivers stopped to help Di Dio. He was taken to Mater Dei Hospital, where he said he had to wait between six to seven hours before being seen. “That was horrible. I couldn’t take it anymore and began to scream out in pain, and only then did they see me,” he said. He was initially told he had minor injuries and was prescribed painkillers. But after several days, his wounds became increasingly painful and doctors at Saint James Hospital later confirmed they were infected. Alongside the physical injuries, Di Dio said his motorbike was damaged and he incurred around €4,000 in expenses for medical treatment, medications, transport and missed work. “I want a refund for the damages but the most important thing is I want to find out who hit me to avoid future accidents,” he said.  After being treated, Di Dio filed a police report. He hoped CCTV footage from the tunnel would help identify the van. But he said police informed him that the security cameras inside the Ta’ Giorni tunnels do not work. “It’s insane. The policeman told me that none of the cameras they have for the tunnels work,” he said. “I told them that it is impossible but they told me again that none of them work.” In 2020, the government launched a €10 million project to upgrade Malta’s major tunnels, including Ta’ Giorni, which included the installation of security cameras. When asked if the cameras were working on the day of the incident, the transport ministry said: “The Traffic Control Centre did not have CCTV coverage in the mentioned area on the 2nd of July 2025.” The ministry did not answer questions about whether the cameras are operational. Police confirmed that a report on the accident had been filed and investigations are ongoing. In 2022, a Transport Malta spokesperson told Times of Malta that tunnel cameras were linked to the authority’s traffic control centre, and used for both congestion monitoring and automatic incident detection.
top_image_caption: Giovanni Di Dio says he is lucky to have survived the hit-and-run incident earlier this month. Right: Cameras were installed in the tunnels in 2020 but no authority could confirm if they are working. File photo: Matthew Mirabelli

title: Toddler in serious condition after falling into swimming pool
subtitle: The accident happened on Monday evening
content: A 16-month-old boy is in serious condition after falling in a pool in a private residence in Gozo, police said in a statement on Tuesday.  Police were reported of the accident on Monday evening at 7.30pm in a residence in Triq Ġnien Imrik, in Xagħra.  The toddler, found unconscious, was given medical assistance by a medical team before being taken Gozo General Hospital. From there, he was then transported by helicopter to Mater Dei Hospital. Magistrate Simone Grech is leading an inquiry.  Last month, six-year-old Zaylen drowned in a Naxxar swimming pool after he wandered away from his relatives.
top_image_caption: The accident took place in a private residence in Gozo. Photo: Shutterstock

title: Elderly man acquitted of traffic fatality as victim is blamed
subtitle: A motorist had no time to react as a pedestrian crossed the road when the lights were green for traffic
content: A man has been acquitted of causing the death of a pedestrian in Paola in 2018 after finding that the victim caused the incident through negligence and the motorist could do nothing about it. The accident happened at Triq Wied Bladun on May 13, 2018. George Glanville, now 83, from Fgura was accused of having caused the death of his friend, William Cocker. The court heard that on that day, Glanville was driving his Kia Rio on a clear road. The traffic light was green. Behind him a man rode a motorcycle accompanied by a passenger. Cocker suddenly emerged from behind a wall and attempted to cross the road straight in front of Glanville’s car. Glanville told the police he was driving at 40-50 km/hr and stopped the vehicle immediately the accident happened. He got out of his car and spoke to Cocker who was still responsive. He only left the scene after the police allowed him to. Glanville told the police that he was sorry for what had happened, since Cocker was his friend and he had known him for a long time. He also kept visiting Cocker in hospital every two days until his death on May 31.   The motorcyclist who had been following Glanville testified that Cocker just crossed the road suddenly. Glanville hit the pedestrian and stopped the car immediately. The man recalled assisting the driver and the victim, who were two elderly men and knew each other. Another eyewitness said that the pedestrian was crossing on the pedestrian crossing when the lights were green for vehicles. Superintendent Hubert Cini testified that Cocker’s injuries were certified as grievous; however, he was not seen at risk of dying at the time. A post-mortem investigation determined, however, that Cocker’s death was a result of the incident. In their submissions on punishment, the prosecution said the charges were issued after the post-mortem examination showed that the victim’s death was caused by the incident. It also argued that while the pedestrian crossed when the lights were green for vehicles, the driver failed to keep a proper lookout. The defence countered that the victim crossed the road without proper look-out when he should not have even crossed. The driver had no time to react. The court referred to the eyewitnesses who testified how Cocker just crossed the road without waiting for the red lights for vehicles. From their testimony, it emerged that the accused could not reasonably have avoided the incident. The court said that it was convinced that the accused was driving responsibly. The evidence showed that the victim had been negligent in this case and that it led to the unfortunate incident. “For this reason, one cannot say that the accused did not keep a proper look out since the victim’s action was unpredictable and there was nothing that the accused could have done to avoid the incident,” Magistrate Nadine Sant Lia observed. The court ruled that the incident was caused by Cocker’s imprudence, which created an unpredictable emergency that made it impossible and unreasonable for the accused to take timely action and avoid the incident. Glanville was acquitted of having caused Cocker’s death through negligent driving. Magistrate Nadine Sant Lia presided over the case. Superintendent Hubert Cini prosecuted.
top_image_caption: A court has acquitted a motorists of causing a traffic fatality.

title: Passenger dead and driver critical following Lija crash
subtitle: The accident took place between a van and a car earlier on Wednesday morning
content: A 79-year-old woman from Mosta has died and an 81-year-old man is in a critical condition following a road accident in Lija on Wednesday morning.   The collision took place at around 10.30am on Triq il-Mosta and involved a Renault Trafic van and a Suzuki Swift car. Police said the van was driven by a 24-year-old man from Mtarfa. The Suzuki was being driven by the 81-year-old from Mosta, with the 79-year-old woman, also from Mosta, as a passenger.  Emergency services, including members of the Civil Protection Department and a medical team, attended the scene. All three individuals were taken to Mater Dei Hospital for treatment. The woman was certified dead shortly after arrival.  The 81-year-old man is in a serious condition, whle the condition of the van driver was not known at the time of publication. Magistrate Ian Farrugia is leading an inquiry while police investigations are ongoing.
top_image_caption: Crash.

title: Motorcyclist grievously injured in Naxxar accident
subtitle: He lost control of his vehicle and fell off the bike after hitting the pavement
content: A motorcyclist was grievously injured following an accident in Naxxar on Thursday morning. The 65-year old man, who lives in Mellieħa, was driving his Honda motorbike along Triq is-Salina at around 10.15am when he lost control of his vehicle, crashed into the pavement and fell off his motorbike. A medical team was called to assist him and he was taken to Mater Dei hospital by ambulance where he was certified to have sustained grievous injuries. Police investigations are under way.
top_image_caption: A section of Triq is-Salina in Naxxar. File photo: GoogleMaps

title: Motorcyclist and passenger seriously injured in Tarxien traffic accident
subtitle: Investigations indicate the man lost control of the motorbike, causing it to overturn
content: A motorcyclist and his passenger were taken to hospital with serious injuries after a traffic accident in Tarxien the early hours of Thursday morning. Initial investigations indicate that the man, a 40-year-old Tarxien resident, lost control of the Kawasaki motorcycle he was riding at around 4.30am, causing it to overturn. A 33-year-old Latvian woman living in Marsascala was also on the motorcycle when it overturned on Triq San Anard. The pair were treated at the scene before being taken to Mater Dei Hospital, where their injuries were certified as serious. Investigations are ongoing.
top_image_caption: The man and woman were taken to hospital after their motorcycle overturned. Photo: Communications Office, Malta Police Force.

title: 27-year-old motorcyclist killed in Pembroke crash
subtitle: Investigations suggest the victim's motorcycle was involved in collision with a BMW driven by a 22-year-old
content: A 27-year-old motorcyclist was killed in a traffic accident in Pembroke in the early hours of Saturday morning.  Initial investigations suggest a BMW 1 Series driven by a 22-year-old man from St Paul's Bay and a Honda motorcycle driven by the victim, a Paola resident, collided at around 1am on Triq Sant’Andrija. The victim was treated at the scene before being taken to Mater Dei Hospital, where he was pronounced dead a short time later.  Police investigations are ongoing.
top_image_caption: Photo: Communications Office, Malta Police Force.

title: One dead in collision involving PM’s parents; George Abela and wife 'stable'
subtitle: Former president George Abela and wife Margaret among several involved in crash
content: Updated 6.35 pm  A woman died and another is in a critical condition following a crash involving Robert Abela's mother and father. The Prime Minister's parents – former president George Abela and Margaret Abela – were among several people hospitalised following a head-on collision between two cars in Fgura on Sunday afternoon. Shortly after the accident, Prime Minister Robert Abela said his mother and father were in a stable condition in hospital. In a statement, police said the individuals were certified as "grievous". In a statement, the police said the 71-year-old woman from Żabbar was pronounced dead shortly after the incident.  A 23-year-old woman who was driving the vehicle is in a critical condition. She is also from Żabbar. The crash, between a Toyota Corolla and an Audi Q3, happened at around 3.30 pm on Triq Hompesh, the busy Fgura road leading to Żabbar.  The police said the Civil Protection Department were needed on site.  Magistrate Ian Farrugia is leading an inquiry into the crash, alongside police investigations.
top_image_caption: Photo: Police

title: Motorcyclist hospitalised following Sliema collision
content:
Tista' taqra bil- Malti.
A motorcyclist was taken to Mater Dei Hospital following a traffic collision in Sliema.
The accident took place at around 11:45am when a car driven by a 71 year old man collided with the motorcycle.
Medical personnel provided assistance at the scene before the 34 year old motorcyclist was taken to Mater Dei Hospital by ambulance.
The condition of the motorcyclist has not yet been confirmed. The other driver did not suffer from any injuries
Authorities are continuing their investigations.

title: Three fatal traffic accidents within a few hours
subtitle: Two women die in separate accidents in Fgura and Valletta and a motorcyclist dies in a crash in Pieta'.
content: Updated. A motorcyclist died in a crash in Pieta' and a woman was fatally injured in Valletta on Sunday evening in the second and third fatal traffic accidents of a tragic day. Earlier another woman died in a car crash in Fgura which involved the prime minister's parents, who were hospitalised. The accident involving the motorcyclist happened at 7.30pm in Marina Street, Pieta’ and involved a 58-year-old man from Żejtun. He lost control of his Honda motorcycle, crashed into a pavement and fell off, police said.  An ambulance crew administered first aid but he died shortly after being admitted to hospital. The second accident  occurred at 10pm when a woman was hit by a car in a freak accident at Ta' Liesse, Valletta close to the fast ferry quay.   The police said a collision occurred between a Subaru Impreza driven by a 23-year-old man from Paola and a Ford Fiesta which was stopped by the side of the road. The woman, 62 of Hamrun, was trapped between the two vehicles. A 69-year-old man who was in the Fiesta was also injured. The woman died on the spot.  Magisterial inquiries are under way.
top_image_caption: A motorcyclist died in Marina Street, Pieta'. Police photo.

title: 'Your life was cut too soon': Mildred Azzopardi killed in tragic Valletta crash
subtitle: Mother-of-four was caught between two vehicles near the Valletta sea front
content: A mother-of-four who died when she was trapped between two cars in a crash on Sunday has been named as Mildred Azzopardi.  The 62-year-old from Ħamrun was at Ta' Liesse in Valletta, when a Subaru Impreza driven by a 23-year-old man from Paola collided with a Ford Fiesta which was stopped by the side of the road. She was trapped between the two cars at the time and died on the spot. In a heartfelt message shared on Facebook, her sister, Frida Farrugia, expressed grief at the way her sister's “life was cut short too soon”.  “You will always be remembered by us, your siblings, as a guiding light and loved till we meet again. You will be sorely missed…. I love you to death my dearest sister. Look after your children, your husband and your little grandchildren,” her sister wrote. The woman had been fishing shortly before the accident on Sunday at 10pm.   She was the third person to die on the roads in three separate accidents on Sunday. Earlier that evening, at about 7.30pm, in Marina Street, Pieta’ a 58-year-old man from Żejtun lost control of his Honda motorcycle, crashed into a pavement and fell off. He died soon after. In the afternoon, a 71-year-old woman died and another is in a critical condition following a two-car crash involving Robert Abela's mother and father – former president George Abela and Margaret Abela. The crash happened at around 3.30pm on Triq Hompesh, the busy Fgura road leading to Żabbar. A 23-year-old woman from Żabbar who was driving the vehicle is in a critical condition. Prime Minister Robert Abela later said his parents were in a stable condition in hospital.
top_image_caption: Mildred Azzopardi was killed in a traffic accident. Photo: Facebook

title: Man dies after being hit by a bus at Floriana Park and Ride
subtitle: The man was pronounced dead at Mater Dei hospital
content: A 63-year-old man from Naxxar has died after being hit by a bus at the Floriana Park and Ride facility.  The accident happened at around 1.45 pm on Tuesday. He was taken to Mater Dei Hospital by ambulance, where he was being treated for serious injuries, police said. He was later pronounced dead. It is the fifth fatal accident on Malta's roads in just four days.  On Saturday, a 27-year-old motorcyclist was killed when his bike was involved in a crash with a BMW in Pembroke in the early hours of the morning.  The following day a woman died in a head-on crash in Fgura that also involved former president George Abela and his wife. A motorcyclist died in Pieta a few hours later.  And on Sunday evening  mother of four, Mildred Azzopardi, died when she was trapped between two cars in a crash on Sunday evening. A 23-year-old soldier has been charged with involuntary homicide for Azzopardi's death.
top_image_caption: A man has died after being hit by a bus. Photo: Chris Sant Fournier

title: ‘Chaos on the roads is growing’: PN
subtitle: Number of accidents at sea is also increasing, opposition says
content: The Nationalist Party has accused the government of lacking political will to tackle the “growing chaos” on Malta’s roads and seas.   The party was reacting to a spate of traffic accidents in recent days that left several people dead and others seriously injured.  At a press conference on Wednesday, shadow minister for transport Mark Anthony Sammut noted that halfway through the year, there had already been 12 traffic deaths.  “It’s clear that the chaos on our roads is growing. In the face of this, the [transport] minister remains silent,” he said, reiterating PN’s call for a national action plan on road safety.  Sammut offered several explanations for the root cause of traffic accidents, including motorists getting frustrated by delays and congestion, and a lack of education on the rules of the road.   “But the primary cause is a lack of law enforcement. The fact is that you barely ever see traffic officers. We need effective and continuous enforcement, not just during the Christmas period. To make matters worse, penalties are not harsh enough for people who kill and maim pedestrians.”  He added that the number of motorists driving under the influence of alcohol and drugs, especially cannabis and cocaine, was also on the rise.  If the PN were elected to government, Sammut said, it would prioritise the sector with a series of specific measures, such as launching an education campaign on how to share the road, while providing better infrastructure for cyclists and motorcyclists.   Sammut also observed that the transport safety investigative commission, first mooted in 2023, had still not been set up.  ‘Reports of incidents at sea have more than doubled’  Meanwhile, PN spokesman for maritime affairs Ivan Castillo said Malta’s seas were also becoming more unsafe, citing figures that showed maritime incidents had increased from 17 to 41 in the space of just four years.   “Enforcement is not increasing at the same rate. There is a clear problem with resources dedicated to enforcement and safety at sea. It’s impossible for officers to keep up with the increasing number of vessels navigating our seas,” Castillo said.  He recalled that the government had spent 100,000 on RHIBs, the vessels used by TM’s Maritime Division, after five rigid hull inflatable boats that were bought for €721,000 were subsequently found to be unseaworthy.  Darren Carabott, the shadow minister for home affairs, said that every accident meant there were family and friends who were grieving or waiting desperately for good news from hospital.  “We can have the best laws on paper, but they are for nothing if there is no proper enforcement,” he said.  On Saturday, a 27-year-old motorcyclist was killed in a traffic accident in Pembroke. The following day, a 62-year old woman died when she was trapped between two cars in a crash in Floriana. Three fatalities in three separate incidents occurred the following day. A 71-year-old woman lost her life following a crash in Fgura, which also involved Prime Minister Robert Abela’s mother and father.   Later on Sunday, a 58-year-old man lost control of his Honda motorcycle in Pietà before crashing into a pavement. He died soon after. And that evening, a 62-year old woman died when she was trapped between two cars in a crash in Valletta. Her husband is in critical condition. On Tuesday, a 63-year-old Tallinja driving instructor was killed when a bus rolled back on him at the Floriana park and ride facility. The man, Karmenu Muscat, was a former footballer who played for Malta’s national team.  And last week, a 79-year-old woman died in an accident in Lija.  Cycling group lists proposals for road safety In a separate statement on Wednesday, the Rota cycling group also called for immediate action to tackle the situation on the roads, pointing out that Malta is on a devastating trajectory to exceed the 2022 record of 26 road deaths in a year. "We cannot continue to treat road deaths as isolated incidents or unfortunate inevitabilities. These are systemic failures: failures in enforcement, infrastructure design, and in political will," the group said. The group said road design must be such that it prioritised the safety of all users, especially the most vulnerable: pedestrians and cyclists.  Malta also needed law enforcement that matched the scale of the crisis. "It is absurd that the Malta Police Force is expected to carry out effective enforcement with only 18 breathalysers at its disposal. Road safety is not achieved through slogans—it requires proper resources, strong policy, and sustained enforcement," it said. The group suggested the immediate rollout of average speed cameras, not just single-point speedtraps; implementation and enforcement of 30 km/h zones in all urban areas; regular, well-resourced spot checks and sobriety testing; proper maintenance of roads, pavements and cycle lanes and proper law enforcement, including fines that reflected the gravity of endangering human life. Legislative reform The group also called for stricter penalties for motorists responsible for killing or seriously injuring pedestrians or cyclists and the introduction of presumed liability, a principle already in place across most EU member states, which places greater responsibility on drivers in the event of collisions with vulnerable users
top_image_caption: The Nationalist Party reiterated its call for a national action plan on road safety. Photo: Partit Nazzjonalista.

title: Ex-footballer Alfred Azzopardi 'fighting for life' after crash that killed wife
subtitle: Son gives update and pays tribute to mother Mildred Azzopardi
content: The son of former Malta footballer Alfred Azzopardi says he is fighting for his life after a car crash that killed his wife on Sunday.  Cain Azzopardi paid a heartbreaking tribute to his mother, Mildred, who was crushed to death when a Subaru Imprezza crashed into the parked family car. The driver of the Subaru Impreza, 23-year-old soldier Benjamin Chetcuti, has been charged with involuntary homicide and drink-driving. He denies all charges. "You didn't deserve this ma after someone irresponsible took your life, we miss you so much and we keep pushing forward as dad keeps fighting for his life," Cain Azzopardi wrote on Facebook on Wednesday. "My best friend, we won't be visiting the Pyramids in Egypt together like we always wanted to. But I know you will there with me. I love you ❤️"  Another of the victim's four children, Amy Azzopardi, shared details of her funeral, which will be held at 9.15am on Saturday at the Floriana Saint Publius Church.  She asked mourners not to wear black, but instead dress in colour "preferably turquoise or orange her favourite colours". The couple had finished a fishing trip at the Valletta waterfront when the crash happened at Ta' Liesse in Valletta. Mildred Azzopardi, 62, was outside the parked Ford Fiesta while her husband Alfred Azzopardi, 69, was inside.  Alfred Azzopardi is a popular figure in Ħamrun, given his successful career as a football player with Ħamrun Spartans during their golden years in the 1980s. He played as a defender, spending over 10 years with the Spartans, helping the Reds to Premier League promotion in season 1975-76. His best years with the Spartans arrived in the 1980s as he helped his club to a league and cup double in season 1982-83 and the FA Trophy the following campaign. In season 1985-86, he helped the Reds to lift the Euro Cup. During his career, Azzopardi also donned the colours of Hibernians and was selected to represent the Malta national team, where he collected eight international caps.
top_image_caption: Former national squad football player Alfred Azzopardi (L), pictured here in 1985, was seriously injured in Sunday's Valletta crash. Photo: Malta and International Football Collection/Facebook.

title: Karmenu Muscat, driving instructor who died in bus accident, was an Olympian
subtitle: Muscat represented Malta in cycling at the 1980 Moscow Olympic Games
content: Karmenu Muscat, the Tallinja driving instructor who died on Tuesday after a bus rolled back on him, was part of Malta’s representation in the 1980 Olympics. In a tribute post to the 63-year-old, the Maltese Olympic Committee said Muscat’s Olympian legacy will not be forgotten. “Karmenu proudly represented Malta in cycling at the 1980 Moscow Olympic Games,” the MOC said, adding they are “deeply saddened” by his passing. Muscat was among only a handful of Maltese athletes in the Games held 45 years ago.  As part of the cycling team, Muscat participated in the team trials where Malta finished in the 20th position out of 23 nations, beating Libya, Cameroon and Ethiopia. The MOC sent their condolences to Muscat’s family and loved ones. Muscat, who was a bus driving instructor, was caught between a back-rolling bus and a wall during the Tuesday afternoon incident at the Floriana Park and Ride.  A medical team was on site and Muscat was taken immediately to Mater Dei Hospital but died shortly afterwards. In a Facebook post, Malta's public transport operator Tallinja said the organisation was "deeply saddened by the tragic loss of our colleague and dear friend, Karmenu Muscat, who passed away today in a devastating accident". The company described him as someone many looked up to for his “patience, professionalism, and dedication”.
top_image_caption: Muscat, who was a bus driving instructor was caught between a back-rolling bus and a wall. Photo: Malta Public Transport

title: Insurers join calls for random drug and alcohol testing of motorists
subtitle: 'Urgent need for stronger enforcement', insurers association warns
content: Insurers have backed a leading doctor’s calls for random drug and alcohol testing of motorists. In a statement, the Insurance Association Malta said it “fully supports” Mater Dei emergency department doctor Jonathan Joslin “regarding the urgent need for stronger enforcement and deterrents to address drink and drug driving on our roads.” Joslin called for random testing of motorists in an article published in Monday’s Times of Malta, when he described the lack of legal provisions for such testing as a “critical gap” in enforcement. Referencing data collected by its members in 2022 that found that only around three per cent of serious traffic accidents saw the use of breathalysers, the association said the situation “remains a cause for concern”. It noted it had “long advocated for more robust enforcement in this area”, including participating in the Malta Road Safety Council and proposing legal amendments putting roadside drug testing on the same level of importance as alcohol testing. The association said it “remains committed to supporting road safety measures, as demonstrated in the past with the donation of breathalyser equipment”. “We continue to call on authorities to prioritise investment in the resources and training needed to enable police to carry out consistent, effective roadside testing, particularly in the context of serious traffic accidents.”  It stressed that a “visible and active police presence is not a sign of excessive enforcement but rather a proven deterrent against dangerous driving behaviour”, noting evidence showed that increased monitoring of motorists during the festive season “directly contributes to improved outcomes”. The association urged authorities to “implement both alcohol and drug testing measures more systematically and without delay”. “Road safety is a shared responsibility—and it deserves unwavering commitment.” Joslin said the country should urgently introduce legal provisions allowing police to conduct random breath and saliva testing for alcohol and drugs, with a shift away from the requirement of “reasonable suspicion” essential to deter would-be offenders. The doctor also said the police must have a visible and routine presence on the roads, with random checkpoints, unmarked patrol vehicles, mobile testing units and immediate roadside suspensions of drivers who fail tests. Last weekend saw saw three fatal crashes within hours of each other. On Sunday night, mother-of-four Mildred Azzopardi was killed when she was caught between two cars after a car driven by a soldier crashed into a stationary vehicle in Valletta. The driver, Benjamin Chetcuti, is charged with involuntary homicide, driving under the influence and grievously injuring another man through negligence.
top_image_caption: Insurers joined calls for random testing of motorists. Photo: Shutterstock.

title: Brazilian motorcyclist grievously injured in Ħal Għaxaq accident
subtitle: The accident happened at 6pm on Wednesday
content: A motorcyclist was grievously injured following an accident in Ħal Għaxaq on Tuesday evening.  The accident occurred at around 6pm in  Triq Dawret Ħal Għaxaq. It involved  a Madison motorcycle driven by a 29-year-old Brazilian man, a Żurrieq resident, and a Volvo XC60 driven by a 42-year-old man from Ħal Għaxaq. The motorcyclist was taken to Mater Dei Hospital by ambulance, where he was certified to have sustained serious injuries. Investigations are ongoing.
top_image_caption: Times of Malta file photo

title: 1,000 requests for emergency ambulances in five days
subtitle: Emergency doctor Michael Spiteri calls on people to be more sensitive and avoid filming or photographing accidents
content: The emergency services were called to assist 1,000 people over five days with cases ranging from fatal and life-threatening accidents to people who consumed too much alcohol, emergency doctor Michael Spiteri has said. Speaking on TVM news, Spiteri noted that between Thursday and Monday, the emergency ambulance service attended over 200 cases daily. “Half of the 1,000 calls for assistance included people with serious problems [who did not need immediate medical assistance for survival], and 10% of them were in a critical situation in which, a few minutes could make a difference between life and death”, he said. Spiteri appealed to people who happened to be passing near an accident, to keep away from the site in order not to disrupt the emergency doctors. He called for more sensitivity and for people not to film or photograph accidents, saying this caused psychological damage to patients and their relatives. Over the past days, there were five fatalities on the road. On Saturday, a 27-year-old motorcyclist — Bulgarian Tenyo Kosev — was killed when his bike was involved in a crash with a BMW in Pembroke in the early hours of the morning. The following day, a woman died in a head-on crash in Fgura that also involved former president George Abela and his wife. A motorcyclist died in Pietà a few hours later. And on Sunday, evening mother-of-four, Mildred Azzopardi, died when she was trapped between two cars in a crash. A 23-year-old soldier has been charged with involuntary homicide for her death. On Tuesday, 63-year-old Tallinja driving instructor Karmenu Muscat, died after a bus rolled back on him at the Floriana Park and Ride facility at around 1.45 pm.
top_image_caption: The emergency services received 1,000 calls in five days. Photo: Matthew Mirabelli

title: Random drug and alcohol testing of motorists ‘long overdue’
subtitle: Introduction of random testing 'long overdue', party says
content: Momentum has joined calls for the introduction of random drug and alcohol testing of motorists. In a statement Friday, the party urged “immediate action” on the issue, saying it “fully supports” a call by Mater Dei emergency department doctor Jonathan Joslin for random testing of road users. Joslin made the appeal after three people died in three separate accidents on Sunday, calling the lack of legal provision for such testing “one of the most critical gaps in current road safety enforcement”. Momentum said the introduction of random testing – not requiring reasonable suspicion – was “not just a necessary step, it is long overdue”. “Too many lives have been shattered, too many families left broken, and too many near-misses ignored. Road safety in Malta cannot wait for another tragedy. We must act with urgency and determination”, the party said. “Momentum stands firmly behind the implementation of random testing, in line with proven international best practices that have saved lives across Europe.” The party stressed that driving while under the influence of alcohol or drugs was “not a ‘personal choice’; it is a public threat”. “Random testing is not about punishing people, it is about deterrence, about prevention, and about protecting innocent lives. Allowing reckless behaviour on our roads to go unchecked is something we should all be worried about.” Momentum committee member Matthew Agius said that while the party was encouraged by growing awareness of the issue, “awareness without action is meaningless”. “It is time for Parliament, authorities, and enforcement agencies to rise to the occasion and introduce a robust, transparent and fair system of random roadside testing, one that is backed by law, supported by technology, and enforced consistently.” The party emphasised placing a “culture of responsibility, accountability, and safety” at the centre of transport policy, warning there was “no room for complacency”. It called on the government to fast-track legal changes to combat the issue and advocated for roads to be built to encourage motorists to drive slower. On Wednesday, insurers added their voice to the calls for random testing.
top_image_caption: The party called for "immediate action" on the issue. File photo.

title: Deadliest week for road fatalities in at least 25 years
subtitle: Road design could reduce accidents, according to transport researcher and road safety advocate
content: Six people were killed between July 23 and 29, marking the deadliest week on Malta’s roads in at least 25 years, a toll that one expert says is a result of chronic failure to prioritise safety in road design. Data compiled by transport activist Paolo Cassar Manghi shows that no other seven-day period since at least 2000 has recorded so many road deaths. Cassar Manghi, a transport researcher and road safety advocate, described the spike in fatalities as “tragic but not surprising”, warning that the country’s road infrastructure often encourages speed rather than discouraging risk. Among the six victims were a driving instructor crushed by a runaway bus, a motorcyclist and a pedestrian killed in a crash involving a parked car. On the same week, three others were killed in unrelated violent incidents, in one of the bloodiest weeks in Malta on record. On July 23, a 79-year-old woman from Mosta died after the Renault van she was a passenger in crashed with a Suzuki Swift car in Lija. Three days later, Tenyo Kosev died when his Honda motorcycle was involved in a collision with a BMW 1 Series motorcycle in Pembroke at around 1am. Last Sunday, three people died. Mildred Azzopardi was crushed to death after a vehicle ploughed into a parked car, fatally hitting the 62-year-old. Azzopardi’s husband, Alfred, was critically injured. Benjamin Chetcuti, who was driving the car that hit the Azzopardis, is facing charges of manslaughter and driving under the influence of alcohol. The other two victims were a motorcyclist and a car passenger who was involved in a collision with a car driven by former president George Abela with his wife Margaret in the passenger seat.  Transport Minister Chris Bonett, however, has insisted that the police unit is not a replacement for the bureau and the two bodies will work together. “Two types of investigation are carried out: to establish what led to an accident, and second, to see what happens next... the idea is to work together,” he said in June. Bonett later clarified that the bureau’s main task will be to analyse how to make roads safer and recommend changes. A terrible week made worse by double murder, death after hotel brawl The bloodbath in Malta was exacerbated with the murder of two men and another who died following a fight. Two men – Anthony Agius and Dennis Mifsud – were shot dead in the Kunċizzjoni area of Baħrija. Seventy-two-year-old Carmelo Ciantar has been arrested over the crime. Separately, Roderick Sciortino died on Thursday following a hotel brawl in Mellieħa. His death remains under investigation, with conflicting reports over whether a pre-existing brain tumour contributed to his collapse.
top_image_caption: Anthony Agius and Dennis Mifsud were shot in Rabat.

title: Crashes snarl traffic on major arteries
subtitle: Accidents in Marsa, Mosta Road Lija, the Rabat road and the Kirkop tunnels
content: Updated 6.40pm A motorcyclist was injured in a traffic accident on a northbound lane of Marsa's Triq Aldo Moro on Monday afternoon.  The incident was reported at around 3.30pm, a police spokesperson said.  The rider, a 67-year-old man from Tarxien was riding a Kymco Skytown motorcycle that collided with a BMW i13 driven by a 79-year-old Sliema woman.  He was taken to Mater Dei Hospital by ambulance. No information about his medical condition was available at the time of writing.  Police cordoned off a section of two lanes on the busy thoroughfare as they worked to clear the scene. The incident led to significant traffic tailing back on the busy road.  The road was fully reopened by 6.30pm, a police spokesperson said.  Mosta Road closed Traffic was also reduced to a standstill in Mosta Road, Lija. A collision between two cars in mid-afternoon caused the busy road to be closed in both directions.  Kirkop tunnel partially closed Meanwhile, one of the Kirkop tunnels was damaged when its roof was hit by a trailer carrying a raised earth shovel. The accident happened at about 6pm and initially caused the closure of the south-bound tunnel. Traffic was later eased when one of the lanes was reopened.  Rabat Road crash A long traffic jam also formed on the Rabat road, Saqqajja, following a collision between a route bus and a car. Both sides of the road were closed for some time. No one was injured.
top_image_caption: Car debris is scattered on Mosta Road, Lija.

title: Former president George Abela and his wife discharged from hospital
subtitle: Couple to continue recovery from home following Fgura car crash
content: Former president George Abela and his wife Margaret, who suffered serious injuries following a traffic accident a week ago, have been discharged from hospital. The couple, who are also the parents of Prime Minister Robert Abela, were discharged late last week and are now “recovering slowly at home”, a spokesperson for the Department of Information said. They were amongst others injured in a head-on collision between a Toyota Corolla and an Audi Q3 on July 27 at 3.30 pm on Triq Hompesh, the busy Fgura road leading to Żabbar. A 71-year-old woman from Żabbar involved in the collision was pronounced dead shortly after the incident. Her 23-year-old daughter was also in a critical condition but has since been discharged. Besides George and Margaret Abela, three others were in the Audi: a 42-year-old woman and two boys aged 14 and 11. George Abela, 77, served as president of Malta from 2009 to 2014. Before that he was a senior figure in the Labour Party, serving for a time as deputy leader. He was also a candidate for the role of party leader in 2008. The week between July 23 and 29 was the deadliest week on Malta’s roads in at least 25 years, with multiple fatalities reported.
top_image_caption: Former president George Abela and his wife Margaret. Photo dates back to 2013.

title: St Paul’s Bay saw the most traffic accidents last quarter – NSO
subtitle: The locality saw 240 accidents over three months
content: St Paul’s Bay was the locality with the highest number of road traffic accidents from April to June, according to figures released Tuesday. The locality saw some 240 accidents, followed by Birkirkara and Qormi, which saw 226 and 210 cases respectively, the National Statistics Office (NSO) said. Nationwide, there were more than 4,000 traffic accidents in the second quarter of the year, a reduction of nine per cent compared to the same period the year before. With one third of accidents, some 1,366 cases, the Northern Harbour District – comprising localities such as Sliema, St Julian’s, Birkirkara and Qormi – was the most accident-prone. There were five fatalities from traffic incidents in the second quarter of the year, all in June, while 108 people were left grievously injured, including 73 drivers, 13 passengers and 22 others, such as pedestrians and cyclists.  Thursdays were the worst for road traffic casualties, amounting to 58, while Tuesdays were the worst for accidents overall, seeing some 645 cases, or 16% of the total. Motorists were most likely to have accidents in the mornings between the hours of 9am and midday, when there were more 884 cases, while 3am to 6am was the safest time to be on the roads, accounting for just 33 incidents. Some 13 cyclists were involved in traffic accidents, one fatally. Three suffered grievous injuries and nine suffered slight injuries. So far this year, 17 people have died on Malta’s roads. Six died in July, five were killed in June, one in May, one in April, one in February and three in January. In 2022, Malta’s deadliest year on record, 14 had died by August 1. By the end of that year, 26 people were killed on the road.
top_image_caption: Graphic: NSO.

title: Two people left with serious injuries in separate traffic accidents
subtitle: The incidents took place in Marsa and Lija in the afternoon
content: Two people were left with serious injuries in separate traffic accidents on Monday. The first incident occurred at around 3.30pm on Aldo Moro Street in Marsa, when a Kymco motorcycle ridden by a 67-year-old man from Tarxien and a BMW I3 car driven by a 79-year-old Sliema woman were involved in a collision. The man was treated at the scene before being taken to Mater Dei Hospital. The second incident took place at around 5pm on Triq il-Mosta in Lija, when a collision occurred between a Mercedes A180 driven by a 28-year-old man from Birkirkara and a Renault Megane driven by a 36-year-old Naxxar woman. The 28-year-old was treated at the scene and taken to Mater Dei. Both hospitalised motorists were certified as suffering from serious injuries. Police investigations are ongoing.
top_image_caption: The scene of the Lija crash. Photo: Communications Office, Malta Police Force.

title: Three people seriously injured in two traffic accidents
subtitle: The accidents took place in Naxxar and Żabbar
content: Three people were taken to hospital yesterday with serious injuries following traffic accidents in Naxxar and Żabbar. The first accident occurred at around 11.30 am, when a Nooma Bravo GLE motorbike driven by a 48-year-old Bulgarian resident of St. Paul’s Bay was involved in a collision with a Hyundai I10 driven by a 60-year-old Spaniard on Triq is-Salina in Naxxar. The second accident took place around an hour later, when a Fiat Scudo driven by a 23-year-old man from Kirkop and a Honda NSS motorbike driven by a 45-year-old man from Żabbar, with an eight-year-old boy riding as passenger, collided. All those involved were treated at the scene, with both motorcycle riders and the eight-year-old passenger taken to Mater Dei Hospital, where their injuries were certified as serious. Police investigations are ongoing.
top_image_caption: NULL

title: Eight-year-old and two motorcyclists seriously injured in two traffic accidents
subtitle: The accidents took place in Naxxar and Żabbar
content: Two motorcycle drivers and an eight-year-old boy were taken to hospital yesterday with serious injuries following traffic accidents in Naxxar and Żabbar. The first accident occurred at around 11.30 am, when a Nooma Bravo GLE motorbike driven by a 48-year-old Bulgarian resident of St. Paul’s Bay was involved in a collision with a Hyundai I10 driven by a 60-year-old Spaniard on Triq is-Salina in Naxxar. The second accident took place around an hour later on Triq Bormla in Żabbar, when a Fiat Scudo driven by a 23-year-old man from Kirkop and a Honda NSS motorbike driven by a 45-year-old man from Żabbar, with an eight-year-old boy riding as passenger, collided. All those involved were treated at the scene, with both motorcycle drivers and the eight-year-old boy taken to Mater Dei Hospital, where their injuries were certified as serious. Police investigations are ongoing.
top_image_caption: Two motorcyclists and an eight-year-old boy were taken to hospital with serious injuries. File photo.

title: Cab ploughs into hairdresser's salon in Santa Venera
subtitle: The salon is believed to have been empty at the time
content: Updated 9.56am A taxi crashed into a hairdresser's salon in Santa Venera on Thursday morning. The car, a Y-plate vehicle, ploughed into Marica's Salon on Cannon Road at around 8am, with police and Civil Protection Department officers on the scene shortly after. A visit to the site showed the car almost completely inside the salon after smashing through the glass at the front of the business. Nobody is believed to have been inside the salon at the time. The driver of the vehicle is believed to have been taken to hospital after sustaining injuries in the crash. The salon describes itself as being in Santa Venera, and is located on the border between the locality and Ħamrun. More to follow.
top_image_caption: The car

title: Woman in hospital after overturning car in San Ġwann valley
subtitle: 25-year-old Swieqi resident taken to hospital following Triq il-Pellikan crash
content: A 25-year-old woman was taken to hospital on Saturday morning after she overturned her car while driving through the San Ġwann valley. The woman, who lives in Swieqi, was driving a Volkswagen Polo on Triq il-Pellikan at around 7.30am when she lost control of the vehicle and overturned it. She was extracted from the vehicle and taken to hospital by ambulance for treatment. No information about her medical condition was available at the time of writing, but a police spokesperson said her injuries were not critical. The road was temporarily closed to traffic while officers cleared the scene.
top_image_caption: The woman was taken to Mater Dei Hospital.

title: Companies rally to help Sta Venera hair salon after car crash
subtitle: Local businesses offer free services to clear wreckage and help business 'get back on its feet'
content: A number of companies have offered to help the owner of a Santa Venera hair salon to clear up the wreckage and debris for free after a car smashed through the shop’s glass doors. The salon was extensively damaged on Thursday morning after a Y-plate cab ploughed into the salon’s glass doors at speed, smashing through furniture and stopping just in front of the reception desk. CCTV footage showed the accident left shattered glass, broken furniture and other debris. On Friday, JA Transport left a message on popular Facebook group Are You Being Served to reach out to the owner of Marica’s Salon offering the company’s services for free, saying they were available to help her “get back on her feet as quickly as possible”. Maverick Baldacchino, the hair salon owner’s son, replied: “May there be more people like you in the world”. Other companies quickly followed JA Transport’s initiative. JG Cleaning Services offered their help for free while Bieb u Għatba turnkey project management company said “let us know how we can give you a helping hand”. Amai beauty salon offered the hairdresser a work station.  The companies’ “heartwarming” offer for help was met with a considerable response with many commenting on the “positive and amazing gesture” and remarking that “there are not many people of goodwill left like you”. The salon on Canon Road was empty at the time of the accident and the owner, Marica Baldacchino, happened to be out feeding stray cats. The driver, a 42-year-old man from Somalia who resides in St Paul's Bay sustained slight injuries. In a social media post, the hairdresser's son Maverick wrote the salon would be open for business as usual on Friday, the morning after the accident, despite the damage sustained to the outlet.
top_image_caption: Before and after: Marica's hair salon in Santa Venera was extensively damaged after a car smashed through its glass doors.

title: Hit-and-run victim named as food courier father-of-three Khim Bahadur Pun
subtitle: Doctors call for road safety action
content: Updated 5.42pm with doctors' call road safety action The 42-year-old motorcyclist who was killed in a horrific hit-and-run in Birkirkara early on Sunday morning has been named as Khim Bahadur Pun from Nepal. A father of three young children, Pun moved to Malta three years ago and was working as a food courier. He is the 18th person to have died on Malta's roads this year.  Police said the 42-year-old victim, who was residing in Birkirkara, died after a Maserati Levante crashed into the Kymco motorbike he was driving.  Following the impact, the Maserati crashed into three parked vehicles and the three people inside it fled on foot. The 17-year-old driver and his father have been arrested. In a Facebook post, the Non-Resident Nepali Association (NRNA) said they were shocked by the news of Pun's death, all due to an unfortunate road accident.   These, the NGO said, are not radical proposals - they are basic safety measures used successfully worldwide. "The father who died today, and the 17 others before him this year, deserves justice through action. Their families deserve a guarantee that no stone is left unturned so that no other family will endure this preventable heartbreak," the doctors said.
top_image_caption: Khim Bahadur Pun is the motorcyclist who was killed in the horrific hit-and-run accident in Birkirkara. Photo: Matthew Mirabelli/Facebook

title: 17-year-old arrested over fatal hit-and-run, hours after fleeing scene
subtitle: Passenger grievously injured, driver arrested hours after motorcyclist was killed
content: Updated 12.30pm with more details Police have arrested an underage driver believed to have been behind the wheel of a car that killed a 42-year-old motorcyclist in a horrific hit-and-run in Birkirkara early on Sunday.  The driver, a 17-year-old boy, and an 18-year-old passenger, both from Qormi, were arrested hours after the accident, after fleeing the scene on foot.  Initial investigations suggest a Maserati Levante crashed into a Kymco motorbike driven by the victim, a 42-year-old Nepalese man, residing in Birkirkara. The incident happened at 5.20am on Triq Salvu Psaila.  Following the impact, the car crashed into three parked vehicles.  The victim was pronounced dead at the scene of the accident, while the 17-year-old car driver and two passengers left the scene.  One of the passengers, an 18-year-old girl from Mosta, was found a short distance away from the accident and was arrested. She was taken to Mater Dei Hospital, and was later certified to be suffering grievous injuries. It is not yet known if the driver and the other passenger sustained any injuries.  The Maserati is owned by the driver's father, who was also arrested by the police.
top_image_caption: Other cars were damaged in the crash. Photo: Matthew Mirabelli

title: Pedestrian injured in Floriana
subtitle: The accident happened on Triq Nazzjonali at 9am
content: A 72-year-old pedestrian was seriously injured when he was hit by a car on National Road, Floriana. The police said the accident happened at 9am on Sunday when the elderly man was hit by a Peugeot Partner van that was being driven by a 78-year-old man from Birżebbuġa. The victim was hospitalised. The police are investigating.
top_image_caption: A pedestrian was hit by a car in Floriana. File photo.

title: Driver was drunk when cab crashed into hairdresser's salon, court told
subtitle: Court turns down request for bail
content: The motorist who was behind the wheel of a cab that crashed into a hairdresser's shop on Thursday morning was drunk, a court heard during his arraignment on Sunday. Police Inspector Nathan Bugeja told Magistrate Gianella Camilleri Busuttil that the motorist, 42-year-old Somali Abdi Salaan Mahammad Abditon, suffered slight injuries when he lost control of the car and crashed into the salon on Cannon Road, Sta Venera. A breathalyser test in hospital showed an alcohol level of over 100 when he should not have had any alcoholic drink, being a cab driver.  No one was injured in the incident, which happened at about 8am and was recorded on CCTV.  The hairdresser avoided injury because she happened to be outside feeding cats. The defence requested bail, with the legal aid lawyer arguing that his client had not had any previous court cases and did not know the witnesses. The prosecution opposed the request, pointing out that this was a serious case, and the accused had told the police that he wished to speak to the shop's owner. Bail was denied.
top_image_caption: The cab which ploughed into a hairdresser's shop in Sta Venera.

title: Fundraiser for hit-and-run victim hits over €11,000 in less than 24 hours
subtitle: Fast-food chain joins tributes to 'kind' Khim Bahadur Pun
content: A fundraiser for a food courier killed in a hit-and-run on Sunday has raised over €11,000 in less than 24 hours. Khim Bahadur Pun, 42, from Nepal, was carrying his Wolt delivery bag when his motorcycle was hit in  Birkirkara at 5.25am. An underage driver, who was arrested after fleeing the scene, is to be arraigned on Monday in connection with the crash.  The Non-Resident Nepali Association (NRNA) said there had been "huge support" for a fundraiser it set up to help the father-of-three's family and to cover the funeral costs in Nepal.   Khanal described the Nepalese community as "one big family", and said the loss of Pun had deeply affected them all. He said he was deeply moved and grateful to see such "overwhelming" support for Pun. "This generosity not only reflects the kindness and compassion of people here in Malta and beyond, but also gives strength and hope to Khim's family during this incredibly difficult time. It's a powerful reminder that humanity transcends borders, and when we come together, we can truly make a difference." A 17-year-old from Qormi, is due to be taken to court on Monday afternoon.  The motorist was driving his father's Maserati Levante when the crash happened at 5.20am in Psaila Street, Sta Venera. He was arrested several hours later, along with an 18-year-old passenger who also ran away from the scene.  A third passenger, an 18-year-old woman also from Qormi, was arrested minutes after the crash, close to the scene of the crash, having suffered injuries.
top_image_caption: The Nepalese community said there has been a "huge" response to a fundraiser. Photo: Go Fund Me

title: Underage driver set to be arraigned over Sunday's fatal crash
subtitle: He ran away from the scene and was arrested a few hours later
content: A motorist who hit and killed a food courier before crashing into three parked cars is due to be taken to court at noon on Monday. He is expected to face charges of involuntary homicide, reckless driving leading to the death of the 42-year-old motorcyclist from Nepal, driving when he was too young to hold a driving licence, and running away from the scene of the crash. The young man was driving his father's Maserati Levante when the crash happened at 5.20am in Psaila Street, Sta Venera. He was arrested several hours later, along with an 18-year-old woman, a passenger who also ran away from the scene. A third young woman, also a passenger, was arrested minutes after the crash, close to the scene of the crash, having suffered injuries.
top_image_caption: The courier's motorcycle was split in two by the crash.

title: Food courier injured in Mġarr accident
subtitle: He lost control of his motorcycle
content: A food courier was seriously injured when he lost control of his motorcycle and crashed at Mosta Road, Mġarr, late on Sunday. The police said the 33-year-old Indian national, a resident in San Ġwann fell off his motorcycle at about 7pm. He was given first aid by an ambulance crew and hospitalised in a serious condition.  It was the second serious incident involving a food courier on Sunday. Earlier in the day, a Nepalese courier died when his motorcycle was hit by a car driven by an underage motorist in Sta Venera.
top_image_caption: A food courier was seriously injured when he lost control of his motorcycle. Police photo.

title: 2,963 fined for speeding, 554 for lacking road licence in July
subtitle: 778 were using their mobile phone while driving
content: A total of 2,963 drivers were slapped with a fine for speeding in July, LESA said.  In a Facebook post, LESA said that last month, a total of 4,966 contravention tickets were issued to motorists who failed to follow the highway code. It did not issue July 2024 figures for comparative purposes.  Motorists caught driving at up to 15km/h over the limit are handed a €34.94 fine. Those driving over 15km/per hour over the limit are slapped with a €69.88 fine.  Last said that 778 drivers were caught last month using their mobile phones while driving. They were each fined €200 and can end up having nine penalty points on their licence.   For bus and taxi drivers, as well as anyone else carrying passengers as part of their job, the fine was even steeper- €300.  554 found driving without a licence in a month Another 554 motorists were caught driving with no road licence, while another 349 were caught not wearing a seatbelt. Not wearing a seatbelt can land a driver with a €46.59 fine.  Another 322 contraventions were issued for drivers on no-entry roads.  The figures reflect a month in which six people died on Malta's roads, with the deadliest week in at least 25 years marked between July 23 and 29. Among the six victims was Mildred Azzopardi, a mother of four, who died at the scene on July 27, when a car ploughed into her car as she was placing items in the boot.  On Tuesday, a court heard how Chetcuti was five times over the alcohol limit.  Two other people died in separate traffic accidents, also on July 27. A motorcyclist died in an accident the previous day. On July 23, a 79-year-old woman from Mosta died after the Renault van she was a passenger in crashed with a Suzuki Swift car in Lija.
top_image_caption: Close to 3,000 motorists were slapped with a fine for speeding last month. Photo: Times of Malta file photo

title: Man admits to driving without licence and insurance cover
subtitle: The man's licence is suspended until next month
content: A man has pleaded guilty to driving a van without insurance and while his licence was suspended. Omar Alhamdoalgorsh, 27, was accused of driving without a licence and insurance cover, breaching bail conditions and recidivism. Alhamdoalgorsh was caught after being stopped by community police and Transport Malta officials carrying out traffic inspections on Triq Burmarrad in St Paul’s Bay, police inspector Warren Galea told a court Tuesday. The officers asked the accused for a licence and he said he did not have one. The sergeant contacted the Police’s control room and was informed that Alhamdoalgorsh’s licence was suspended until September 12. He was also informed that the man signs the bail book at Qawra Police Station. The man was arrested and arraigned in court on Tuesday afternoon. He confirmed he would plead guilty. While hearing submissions on punishment, the police inspector said this was the second time Alhamdoalgorsh was caught driving without a licence and the law was clear. The inspector said that while the man had adhered to his bail conditions, this incident led to a breach since he committed a crime while out on bail. Galea added that the man regretted having driven without a licence. Defence lawyer Noel Bianco said the man miscalculated and thought the suspension had elapsed and that he was clear to get back behind the wheel. He was also on his way to work when caught driving without a licence. The court fined him €5,500 and disqualified him from having a driving licence for 18 months, beginning after the current suspension elapses on September 12. The court ordered the forfeiture of €1,000 from his personal guarantee but did not revoke his bail. “In these circumstances, you should really be careful. With all these incidents around us caused by the lack of care for traffic regulations, you should really be careful,” Magistrate Jean Paul Grech warned the man before he left the courtroom. Police inspector Warren Galea prosecuted. Lawyer Noel Bianco assisted the accused.
top_image_caption: The man said he thought his suspension had elapsed. Photo: Shutterstock.

title: Breathalyser showed motorist in fatal Valletta crash was five times over limit
subtitle: Mildred Azzopardi, 62, was putting items in the boot of her parked car when the crash happened
content: A breathalyser test on Benjamin Chetcuti, the driver involved in last month's fatal crash in Valletta showed him to be some five times above the legal limit, a court heard on Tuesday. The test returned a reading of 139.2 μg/100ml (microgrammes of alcohol per 100 ml) of breath or about five times the legal limit, Superintendent Nicholas Vella said at the compilation of evidence against Chetcuti, an AFM soldier arraigned last month. He stands accused of the involuntary homicide of Mildred Azzopardi, driving under the influence and grievously injuring Azzopardi's husband through negligence. He denies the charges. Mildred Azzopardi, 62, from Ħamrun, a mother of four, died at the scene on July 27 when Chetcuti's car ploughed into her car as she put items in the boot. The 23-year-old accused joined the AFM as a recruit in January and on June 10 had his passing out ceremony and was confirmed as a gunner. He was posted to the Maritime Squadron on July 1. Police superintendent Nicholas Vella from the Road Policing Unit testified on how the accident happened at Xatt il-Barrieri, where the Azzopardis had earlier been fishing. Vella played out footage from ten CCTV cameras, explaining that the accused drove around Fort St Elmo initially at 36km/hr. His Subaru Impresa could then be seen at a speed of 246.33/m in nine seconds, meaning an average speed of 98 km/hr. The superintendent said Alfred Azzopardi, the victim's husband, was already in their Ford Fiesta while Mildred was putting some stuff away in the boot when the crash took place. CCTV footage taken from the offices of shipping companies in the area showed the Subaru Impresa arriving at a high speed before the driver lost control and it swerved, hitting Mildred Azzopardi' car first. Azzopardi died on the spot.  Medicolegal expert Mario Scerri testified that Mildred Azzopardi sustained several bone fractures and internal haemorrhage. Her husband suffered  grievous injuries and was in intensive care for a while. He added that Chetcuti tested negative for drugs. His urine sample was sent to another expert for further testing. Medicolegal experts Ali Sarfraz and David Pisani took the witness stand and testified jointly on the findings of the post-mortem examination which showed that Mildred Azzopardi suffered multiple injuries. An eyewitness also took the stand on Tuesday morning. Reeves Cini explained that at the time of the incident he was at the nearby Siege Bell Memorial. “When I arrived on site I found Benjamin,” the witness said, clarifying that he knew the accused from the time the latter worked in Valletta. The road had already been closed. The witness said he feared the worst since his grandfather owned a boathouse in the area. He asked Chectuti if he wanted something to drink, and ran up to his home and got him a soft drink from the fridge. Chetcuti told him: “I was coming from Pixxkerija (fishmarket) side when I lost control of the vehicle and crashed into the cars.”
top_image_caption: The victim Mildred Azzopardi.

title: Pedestrian injured as parked car is pushed forward during crash
subtitle: A motorist was also hurt in the crash in Guardamangia
content: Two persons were hospitalised after a car crashed into a parked vehicle in Guardamangia on Tuesday morning. The accident happened at 7am in St Luke's Square, opposite St Luke's Hospital when a Volkswagen crashed into the back of a parked Mercedes. The Mercedes was pushed forward, hitting a man and injuring him. The driver of the Volkswagen was also injured. The police are investigating. No further details were immediately available.
top_image_caption: File photo.

title: Hit-and-run victim's family worry about how they will cope, want justice
subtitle: 'He would send money every month...he told me he was coming back to Nepal very soon,' - victim's sister
