content: The sister of the food courier killed in a hit-and-run on Sunday said his family depends on him to cover everyday expenses, and, now, they are concerned about how the young family will cope. “He would send money every month to cover the children’s fees, school bills, housing bills, everything,” his sister, Nardevi Pun said. “His three children and wife depend on him. Now we are worried how his young family will cope.” Khim Bahadur Pun, 42, from Nepal, was carrying his Wolt delivery bag when his motorcycle was hit by a Maserati car in Birkirkara at 5.25am on Sunday. A 17-year-old driver, who was arrested after fleeing the scene yesterday pleaded not guilty to causing his death and to driving under the influence. Nardevi, 39, who lives in Nepal, said the family are deeply upset and shocked by her brother’s death. Holding back tears, she said the last time she spoke to her older brother was the day before the fatal accident, on Saturday, when the two chatted briefly. “He told me he was coming back to Nepal very soon. He told me that, after three or four months, he would be back,” she said. The middle child of three siblings, Khim moved to Malta over three years ago to work as a courier. His younger sister said their parents are devastated by the news of his death, grieving at the loss of their youngest son. “It was completely unexpected and they are overcome by sadness,” she said. 'Anger and frustration' She described how the family was filled with “anger and frustration” over the loss of Khim, who she described as a “vibrant soul” taken away too soon.  “The circumstances surrounding Khim’s death are unacceptable. This was not an accident; it was a reckless act that resulted in the loss of a precious life. We demand justice for Khim,” she said, highlighting how the driver must be held accountable for their actions. She said Khim’s wife was informed about her husband’s death by his brother’s wife. “She fainted when told and has not stopped crying since,” Nardevi said. She said Khim’s eldest son, who is 14, knows about his father’s death. His younger son, eight, and his six-year-old daughter still do not know. Khim’s sister described him as an honest and hard-working man. “He was a good person and always looked out for others in our community. He was always ready to help someone in need,” she explained. “My family and I are so sad and upset as we lost a huge pillar of our family.” When the family found out the circumstances around Khim’s death, she said the family began to question law and order in Malta. “We want justice for Khim and his family. His family need support and must be kept informed about the case.” €16,000 raised to repatriate the body, help the family Pun’s body will be repatriated on Wednesday a final farewell will be organised by members of the Nepali community outside Mater Dei Hospital at  9am. A vigil for Pun was held by Nepalese nationals near the crash site on Sunday evening, when they lit candles and prayed. A fundraiser organised by the Non-Resident Nepali Association (NRNA) had raised over €16,000 by Monday afternoon to help his family and cover the funeral costs in Nepal. “Seeing this huge support towards the GoFundMe page for Khim shows the kindness and solidarity not only within our own Nepali community but also from the Maltese and other friends around us,” NRNA president, Rems Khanal said.
top_image_caption: Khim, with his younger sister, Nardevi, and their older brother.

title: Watch: Convoy of Wolt and Bolt riders follow coffin of courier killed in crash
subtitle: Hundreds of mourners turned out to pay their respects to Khim Bahadur Pun
content: A convoy of Bolt and Wolt riders have followed the coffin of a courier who was killed in a hit-and-run crash. Hundreds of mourners turned out to pay their respects to Khim Bahadur Pun, 42, who died when the Kymco motorbike he was riding was hit by a Maserati Levante, allegedly driven by an underage driver.  Around 200 delivery drivers in scooters and motorbikes followed the father-of-three's coffin on Wednesday as it made its way to the airport, from where the remains will be repatriated to Nepal. Crowds gathered earlier at the Mater Dei mortuary to pay tribute to Khim, who had been working in Malta for three years before his death.   An unlicensed 17-year-old who was allegedly found to be above the legal alcohol limit has been charged with causing his death. The teenager is also accused of fleeing the scene and failing to inform the authorities. Pun is the second known Nepalese food delivery driver to have been killed in an accident. In February 2022, a truck toppled over on Marsa's Aldo Moro Road, smashing into lampposts and dropping its load of scrap metal onto opposing lanes of traffic, killing 28-year-old Nepali food delivery driver Ajay Shrestha. Eighteen people have so far died on Maltese roads this year.
top_image_caption: The dozens gathered to bid farewell at the Mater Dei mortuary.

title: Motorcyclist seriously injured following Pembroke accident
subtitle: The accident took place at 5.30 am in Triq Sant'Andrija
content: A 21-year-old Italian motorcyclist was rushed to the hospital early on Thursday morning after crashing into a concrete barricade.  A police spokesperson said the accident happened at around 5.30 am in Triq Sant' Sant'Andrija in Pembroke, in St. Andrew's area.  According to investigations, the man lost control of the Kymco Agility motorbike and crashed into the concrete traffic barricade. The motorcyclist was rushed to the hospital for further medical assistance and was certified with serious injuries. The road leading towards the Coast Road is currently closed.  Magistrate Monica Borg Galea is leading an inquiry into the crash.
top_image_caption: The accident took place at around 5.30am in the St Andrew's area. Photo: Facebook/Maltese Roads Traffic Updates

title: 21-year-old who crashed motorcycle in Pembroke dies
subtitle: Italian rider becomes 19th road fatality of the year
content: A motorcyclist who crashed in Pembroke at 5.30am on Thursday has died, the police said in a brief statement on Saturday. The 21-year-old Italian man crashed his Kymco Agility motorbike into a concrete barrier on Triq Sant’ Andrija and was rushed to hospital in a critical condition. Despite medical teams’ best efforts, he subsequently died in hospital. The motorcyclist is the 19th person to die as a result of traffic incidents this year, and the second motorcyclist to die this past week. In a separate, unrelated incident, a motorcyclist was killed by an underage driver who fled the scene last Sunday morning. The driver was subsequently caught, arrested and charged with manslaughter.
top_image_caption: The road where the man crashed, closed off to traffic on Thursday.

title: ‘Why do we have to beg for justice?’
subtitle: Brother of victim of freak 2022 incident calls out delay
content: The brother of a food courier killed in a freak accident more than three years ago is appealing for justice as the magisterial inquiry is still ongoing. In February 2022, 28-year-old Nepali delivery driver Ajay Shrestha died when a truck overturned on Marsa’s Aldo Moro Road. The vehicle ploughed into a lamppost before spilling its load of scrap metal onto oncoming traffic, fatally crushing Shrestha. Shrestha, known to friends as ‘AJ’, had moved to Malta from Nepal in 2018 in search of work. Just a week before the accident, he had celebrated his 28th birthday. “It has been three years now since my brother’s death, and nothing has happened. Nobody has contacted me,” Ajay’s older brother, Anil, told Times of Malta.  Anil recalled how his sibling always had a smile on his face and, during his time in Malta, made a lot of friends. “He was very passionate about sport, he played cricket back at home and loved to play music. He was never angry with anyone and was just a very good person.” He said the two were always together from childhood until the fatal accident changed that. “All my family wants is justice for Ajay. We understand that it was an accident, but we deserve and need this justice and to know that someone is looking into my brother’s case.”
top_image_caption: Ajay with his first motorbike, which Anil bought with his salary. Photos: Anil Shrestha

title: Northbound lane of coast road closed after traffic accident
subtitle: The accident, involving a car and a motorcycle, took place at around 4pm
content: The northbound lane of the coast road in Naxxar, Tul Il-Kosta, was closed after a traffic accident on Sunday afternoon.  The accident at around 4pm saw a motorcycle driven by a 53-year-old man involved in a collision with a car, police said.  Further details, including the condition of the motorcyclist — who is believed to be a foreign national — and the driver of the car, were not available at the time of publication. Police advised motorists to avoid the area and seek alternate routes.
top_image_caption: Police advised motorists to avoid the area. File photo: Matthew Mirabelli.

title: 16-year-old caught driving motorcycle in Żejtun
subtitle: Four others found driving without a licence
content: A 16-year-old was caught riding a motorcycle illegally after being stopped in a routine traffic inspection on Sunday morning.  The inspection on Tal-Barrani netted another four people who were caught driving without a licence, while summons were issued to a further 17 persons in connection with “various irregularities”, police said in a statement.  The motorcycle ridden by the 16-year-old was seized, with investigations ongoing. The legal driving age in Malta is 18.  The inspection was carried out by police and Local Enforcement System Agency (LESA) officers, who appealed for motorists to “observe traffic rules with respect for their lives and the lives of other people on the road”. Last weekend, a courier was killed in a hit-and-run crash involving an underage driver. Khim Bahadur Pun, 42, from Nepal, was killed when a Maserati car allegedly driven by a 17-year-old smashed into his motorcycle in Sta Venera.
top_image_caption: The inspection netted a further four people driving without a licence. File photo: Malta Police Force, Communications Office.

title: Friends launch fundraiser to bring home Italian tourist killed in Pembroke crash
subtitle: Over €28,000 raised in memory of 21-year-old Maichol Di Nunzio
content: The friends of a 21-year old Italian tourist who died following a motorcycle crash in Pembroke have launched an online fundraising campaign to repatriate his body. Maichol Di Nunzio from Primavalle, in the north-eastern part of Rome, crashed his Kymco Agility motorbike into a conrete barrier on Triq Sant’ Andrija early on Thursday morning. He succumbed to his injuries on Saturday. His friends describe di Nunzio as “full of life and always cheerful” but had lived a life full of hardship. He was brought up in a foster home from the age of nine together with his sister Aurora. “They grew up side by side, supporting each other and becoming a vital point of reference for one another,” fundraiser organiser Desire Di Francesco said. “Now, it is Aurora who must face the repatriation of her brother’s body to Italy,” she said, adding that Aurora does not have the financial means to cover the expenses. By Sunday morning the fundraiser had already raised over €28,700, more than half the amount requested, from around 600 donors. The GoFundMe fundraiser can be accessed here.
top_image_caption: Maichol Di Nunzio was killed after he crashed his motorbike in Pembroke.

title: National Alcohol Policy lacks measures to address drink-driving: Insurers
subtitle: The Insurance Association Malta called for random roadside checks and stricter penalties
content: The Insurance Association Malta raised its concerns that the new National Alcohol Policy lacks any robust enforcement measures to address drink-driving.  "With the island still reeling from a tragic number of road fatalities, it is disappointing that proven measures, such as random breath testing and mandatory alcohol testing after accidents, remain absent," the Association said in a press release on Monday. The statement comes after Magistrate Joe Mifsud called for random roadside alcohol and drug testing of drivers, after a fatal Senglea motorcycle crash, which took place in June, revealed the rider had cocaine in his system.  The National Alcohol Policy was launched in June to reduce alcohol consumption in the population through "evidence-based strategies". The Association said it welcomed the policy's release for public consultation, but raised its concern that the publication, which was delayed by 17 months, is a signal of the authorities' lack of urgency, and how it left out a dedicated section on drink-driving found in the 2018-2023 policy.   The Association pointed to the policy's own data showing that alcohol consumption in Malta rose by 23 per cent between 2010 and 2019, while the European average fell by roughly the same percentage. Almost half of those aged 20 to 49 admit to drinking more than six glasses of alcohol each week.  “The policy acknowledges rising alcohol use across all age groups, yet remains practically silent on the sanctions and enforcement that are crucial to deterring repeat offenders. Education alone is the carrot, but without the stick of enforcement, it will not be enough,” IAM said.  The Association urged the government to follow the lead of other European countries, which were implementing tougher laws to curb drink-driving, including random roadside checks and stricter penalties, such as higher fines and licence suspensions.  It also called for mandatory reporting of driving-under-the-influence cases to insurers. It also called for the introduction of Alcolock devices, a breathalyser installed in a vehicle that would prevent the engine from starting if the driver is over the legal limit. It also suggested introducing subsidised taxi services during large events, coupled with campaigns to promote designated drivers. Finally, it suggested greater use of CCTV footage to identify and deter dangerous behaviour on the roads.  “Educating drivers on the risks is vital, but it must be matched by strong deterrents that make repeat offences far less likely,” IAM said.  The statement comes following a spate of serious road accidents in recent weeks, several linked to drink-driving. The Association also called on the authorities to ensure that the new National Alcohol Policy delivered meaningful change, warning that "without decisive measures, Malta risks relegating this policy to another missed opportunity, and drink-driving will remain a deadly, preventable threat on our roads” In July, AFM soldier Benjamin Chetcuti was allegedly five times over the alcohol limit when his car hit 62-year-old Mildred Azzopardi in Valletta, killing her and injuring her husband. The test returned a positive result of 139.2 μg/100ml when the legal limit is 22micrograms. On August 10, food courier Khim Bahadur Pun, 42, from Nepal, was killed when his motorcycle was hit by a car driven by a 17-year-old in Santa Venera.The youth fled the scene but was arrested five hours later. Police said a breathalyser test found he was over the legal alcohol limit.
top_image_caption: The Insurance Association Malta said the island is reeling from a tragic number of road fatalities and called for random roadside drug and alcohol testing. Photo: Shutterstock

title: Magistrate urges random alcohol, drug tests after fatal biker crash
subtitle: Calls for better coordination between the authorities and constant, rather than sporadic, law enforcement presence on the roads
content: A magistrate has called for random roadside alcohol and drug testing of drivers, after a fatal Senglea motorcycle crash revealed the rider had cocaine in his system. Magistrate Joe Mifsud made the recommendation following a magisterial inquiry into the June accident on Triq ix-Xatt Juan B. Azopardo. The 43-year-old motorcyclist lost control, struck a bollard and was killed on the spot. No one else was injured. Toxicology tests conducted during the autopsy found traces of cocaine in his system. In his concluding remarks, Mifsud said that “while it seems that disciplinary measures have started being taken while driving, enforcement needs to increase and officials should be conscious of their role in protecting lives”. He stressed that while discipline has never killed anyone, substance abuse has, with the victims sometimes being innocent, law-abiding citizens who suffer due to the abuse of others. The magistrate urged better coordination between the authorities and constant, rather than sporadic, law enforcement presence on the roads. He referred to a 2023 position paper co-written by NGO Doctors For Road Safety, the Maltese Association of Psychiatry and the Foundation for Welfare Services on drug-driving under the influence of psychoactive drugs.  The paper states that “the use of psychoactive drugs can result in impaired driving skills, leading to an increased risk of road traffic crashes. “It is important to note that the most common psychoactive drugs involved in driving crashes are often taken for recreational purposes, although prescription drugs such as benzodiazepines and opioids can also impair driving skills.” Mifsud endorsed each of the paper’s eight recommendations, including the introduction of a legal framework to enable random drug testing for psychoactive substances, as well as the random screening of professional drivers, such as taxi, school bus, coach and heavy machinery drivers. The paper also called for the establishment of clear guidelines regarding acceptable substance levels in the body while driving, and the review and updating of existing legislation to include penalties for the combined use of drugs and alcohol to reflect the increased risk to road safety. Many European countries allow random or targeted random roadside testing for alcohol or drugs. In the UK, Germany and Malta, the police need “reasonable suspicion” to conduct tests. The Maltese magistrate’s call comes amid a spate of serious road accidents in recent weeks, several linked to drink-driving. In July, AFM soldier Benjamin Chetcuti was allegedly five times over the alcohol limit when his car hit 62-year-old Mildred Azzopardi in Valletta, killing her and injuring her husband. The test returned a positive result of 139.2 μg/100ml when the legal limit is 22micrograms. On August 10, food courier Khim Bahadur Pun, 42, from Nepal, was killed when his motorcycle was hit by a car driven by a 17-year-old in Santa Venera. The youth fled the scene but was arrested five hours later. Police said a breathalyser test found he was over the legal alcohol limit. And earlier this month, a taxi crashed into a hair salon in Santa Venera. The owner, who was outside at the time, was unhurt. Tests showed the driver’s alcohol level exceeded 100mg.
top_image_caption: The site of the fatal bike crash in Senglea. Photo: Matthew Mirabelli

title: Drunk cab driver was waiting for passengers before crash into salon, court hears
subtitle: Driver had reading of 107.3 µg/100 ml when the legal limit for cab drivers is zero
content: A cab driver who was over the legal alcohol limit when he crashed into a Santa Venera hair salon told police he had been waiting for passengers, a court has heard. Abdi Salaan Mahamad Abditon Ali had a reading of 107.3 micrograms of alcohol per 100 ml breath, when the legal limit for cab drivers is zero, after the crash into Marica’s Salon, on Cannon Road, on August 7. A court on Monday heard that he gave a statement to police, in which he said he was waiting for passengers just before the collision. "Thank God no one requested a cab… It could have resulted in fatalities,” police inspector Nathan Bugeja told the court.   The 42-year-old Somali national stands accused of driving in a negligent, dangerous and reckless manner, causing damage to third property, and driving under influence. He denies the charges. The salon was still closed at the time of the incident and there were no injuries. A police constable testified about receiving a call regarding the collision, with the initial information stating that the vehicle had crashed into a “house”. When the witness got onsite, he found the owner, Marica Baldacchino, who had not seen the incident. The witness went to Mater Dei Hospital where he spoke to the driver. He returned back when another constable was subjecting the driver to the a breathalyzer test. The constable underlined that a cab driver’s limit is 0 μg/100ml. During Monday’s sitting, the prosecution and defence made submissions on bail. Police inspector Bugeja objected due to the seriousness of the crime.  Bugeja also highlighted that although the man’s address on his official documents and the charge sheet state that he lives in St Paul’s Bay, the police accompanied him to a Ħamrun address to collect his passport. Defence lawyer Francesca Zarb counter-argued that the defendant has been in Malta since 2008 and this was his first brush with the law. He was granted subsidiary protection and has a residence permit. The lawyer observed that the court as presided hears cases on traffic collisions and argued that individuals with the same charges are brought before it under summons not under arrest. Zarb also argued that whether the man is granted bail or otherwise, the amount of damages would not be affected. Bugeja rebutted the argument stating that usually collisions do not involve third parties, nor do they involve damages running into thousands of euros. While an exact figure was not given during Monday’s sitting, the damages sustained are between €10,000 to €15,000. These will be confirmed once the salon owner takes the stand. The police inspector also added that the man poses a risk to the public. Zarb observed that two of Ali’s friends were present in the courtroom, with one of them willing to host him. The friend told the court that he came to Malta in 2006 and has known the accused for the past eight years. The court then asked the accused whether he held a bank account, signalling it was willing to grant bail, only if a bank guarantee could be made. After establishing that Ali lacked a bank account with a local bank through which he could guarantee at least €10,000 in favour of the victim, the court denied the man bail. In its decision, the court held that it does not have the peace of mind he would be able to satisfy all conditions otherwise imposed by the court in a bail decree, even though at this stage, the man is presumed innocent until proven guilty. The case continues later this month. Magistrate Victor Axiak presided.Police inspectors Nathan Bugeja and Rachel Aquilina prosecuted.Lawyer Francesca Zarb appeared for the accused.Lawyers Zack Esmail and Kaylie Borg appeared parte civile.
top_image_caption: The hair salon was empty when a car ploughed through the window.

title: Elderly man hospitalised after being hit by car in Raħal il-Ġdid
content:
A 75-year-old man from Żabbar was grievously injured this morning after being struck by a car in Triq Ħal Luqa, Raħal il-Ġdid.
The accident took place yesterday at around 4pm.
Police said the vehicle was driven by a 29-year-old man from Santa Luċija.
The pedestrian was taken to Mater Dei Hospital by ambulance.
Investigations are ongoing.

title: Transport Malta unveils traffic management plan for smaller SiGMA conference
subtitle: The plan is the same as last year's
content: Transport Malta revealed its traffic management plan for SiGMA's annual conference, which is expected to have fewer attendees this year.  This year’s event will take place from 1 to 3 September at the Malta Maritime Hub (MMH). Unlike previous year’s this will not be SiGMA’s main event, it will be a smaller event that is expected to attract 15,000 people. The main event is being held in Milan this year. Last year, SiGMA’s main conference attracted around 27,000 delegates. This large event drew criticism for exacerbating traffic congestion, particularly around Marsa, where the conference was held. Despite the complaints, the Traffic Ministry had insisted that its traffic management plan worked. During a media briefing on Wednesday, Transport Malta CEO Kurt Farrugia reiterated that last year's plan worked well, and overall, TM plans on implementing a very similar traffic management plan. The main difference is that more TM officials will be deployed on the first day of the event, and the white taxi drop-off and pick-up point has moved. Just like last year, TM plans on implementing a geo-fenced area for ride-hailing cabs, meaning that Y-plate taxis will not be able to drop off or pick up anyone within the general area of the event. Instead, ride-hailing cabs will have a designated pick-up and drop-off spot, on the other side of Triq il-Labour in ONE News’ parking lot. Attendees will have to walk for about five minutes and cross the bridge over the main road to reach the event. White taxis will have a separate drop-off and pick-up zone located along the road in front of Identità’s office. Chauffeur-driven cabs will use Addolorata Cemetery’s parking area as private parking for their cabs. While anyone catching a coach or mini-bus will be dropped off and picked up on Triq tat-Tromba, which is a seven-minute walk from the venue. Otherwise, staff personnel will have their own designated parking closer to the venue. Besides these different zones, TM officials will be patrolling the area and making use of drones to best monitor the traffic. In an interview with Times of Malta last year, prime minister Robert Abela said that the Malta Maritime Hub is not a viable venue and pledged to find a better venue to host this conference. This is the third consecutive year that the MMH will be used as SiGMA's venue.
top_image_caption: SiGMA's 2024 event. File Photo

title: MHRA backs calls for random roadside testing for drugs and alcohol
subtitle: Hotel and restaurant lobby says 'time for action is now'
content: The Malta Hotels and Restaurants Association (MHRA) has come out in favour of revising laws to allow police to conduct random roadside drug and alcohol checks.  Calls for a change in legislation have been amplified in recent weeks following a spate of fatal or serious crashes involving alcohol or drug-impaired drivers.  Currently, police can only breathalyse drivers if they have a "reasonable suspicion" that drivers are under the influence. Police are only equipped with alcohol breathalysers.  In a statement published on Tuesday, MHRA said it backed a call by emergency doctor Jonathan Joslin, who called for random testing of motorists in a Times of Malta opinion piece published on Monday.  Joslin warned MPs that if they did not revise the law, they would have to bear moral responsibility for any ensuing road deaths in which drugs or alcohol are involved.  The MHRA called for the government and MPs to heed Joslin's call, highlighting how the "time for action is now". "MHRA stresses that for a country like Malta, where tourism is a cornerstone of the economy, safety is not opitional, it is essential," the statement read. The Insurance Association Malta has also backed the doctor's call for random drug and alcohol testing of motorists.  "A safe environment on our roads is just as important as the quality of our hotels, restaurants, and attractions. Tourists choose destinations where they can enjoy themselves with peace of mind, and residents deserve the same assurance every day." MHRA said that random roadside testing would send a clear message that the country people can visit confidently and enjoy responsibly.  "Such measures do not restrict enjoyment, they raise the standard of living and hospitality for everyone."  The past few weeks have seen a string of road accidents and deaths linked to drink-driving.  On Monday, a woman involved in a collision that left a motorcyclist critically injured on Sunday was six times over the legal alcohol limit at the time.  In another recent case, a 42-year-old food courier from Nepal was killed when his motorcycle was hit by a Maserati car in Santa Venera. A 17-year-old driver was later charged after fleeing the scene, and pleaded not guilty to driving under the influence.  Mother-of-four Mildred Azzopardi was killed when she was caught between two cars after a car driven by a soldier crashed into a stationary vehicle in Valletta. The driver, Benjamin Chetcuti, is charged with involuntary homicide, driving under the influence and grievously injuring another man through negligence.
top_image_caption: Hoteliers back doctors call for random roadside testing for drugs and alcohol following a spike in road accidents linked to driving under the influence. Photo: Matthew Mirabelli

title: Bus and car collide on Sliema front
subtitle: Unclear if any injuries
content: A public bus and a car were involved in a collision on Tower Road, Sliema, on Thursday morning, closing the road in both directions. A photo of the incident shows damage to the front of both vehicles. It is not known if anyone was injured in the incident, which occurred at around 5.30am. As of 7.05am, mapping applications were showing no delays on Tower Road.
top_image_caption: The collision happened at around 5.30am.

title: Catering establishments join calls for random substance testing
subtitle: Caterers' association joins hotels and insurers in backing random testing
content: The Association of Catering Establishments (ACE) has joined a chorus of voices calling for the introduction of random drug and alcohol tests of motorists.   Currently, police can only breathalyse drivers if they have "reasonable suspicion" that drivers are under the influence. Police are only equipped with alcohol breathalysers.  Calls for a change in legislation have been amplified in recent weeks following a series of fatal or serious crashes involving alcohol or drug-impaired drivers.   The association referred to “alarming” data compiled in 2022 by the Insurance Association Malta, which is also in favour of random testing, that revealed breathalyser tests were only used in around three per cent of serious traffic accidents.  “This data clearly highlights the need for a revision in the current legislation,” ACE said.  The organisation referred to a recent opinion piece published in Times of Malta by emergency doctor Jonathan Joslin, who wrote that members of parliament would bear moral responsibility for future road deaths involving drugs and alcohol should the law remain unchanged. ACE added that it also supported calls by Caritas for strict ID card checks in supermarkets, groceries and catering establishments.  “Above all, ACE also supports the recent call for a public education campaign aimed at clarifying the risks associated with alcohol consumption and driving to remind the public that any amount of alcohol in the bloodstream can impair their ability to drive safely.”  The association stressed that road safety is a collective effort which calls on government, legislators, political parties, civil society and individuals to ensure safer roads, better enforcement and fewer deaths.  On Monday, the Malta Hotels and Restaurants Association also came out in support of revising laws to allow police to conduct random substance testing.  "MHRA stresses that for a country like Malta, where tourism is a cornerstone of the economy, safety is not optional; it is essential," the association said.  In a recent inquiry into the death of a motorcyclist who was found to have cocaine in his system, Magistrate Joe Mifsud endorsed a 2023 position paper co-written by NGO Doctors For Road Safety, the Maltese Association of Psychiatry and the Foundation for Welfare Services on drug-driving under the influence of psychoactive drugs.   Mifsud endorsed each of the paper’s eight recommendations, including the introduction of a legal framework to enable random drug testing for psychoactive substances, as well as the random screening of professional drivers, such as taxi, school bus, coach and heavy machinery drivers.
top_image_caption: Currently, police can only administer a breathalyser test if they have reasonable suspicion that a motorist is intoxicated. Photo: Shutterstock.

title: Concrete action urged for road safety
subtitle: PN proposes 'zero tolerance' as emergency doctor slams 'unacceptable' situation
content: The Nationalist Party on Thursday called for “concrete action” to address road safety in Malta as an emergency doctor slammed the situation as "unacceptable". The statements came in the wake of another accident caused by drink-driving when a car, driven by a Brazilian man, crashed head on into an oncoming bus in the opposite lane on Tower Road in Sliema. The car driver was four times over the alcohol limit.  Michael Spiteri, who was attending to the first call out of the day at just before 6am on Thursday in the wake of the Sliema accident, warned this could "have ended in tragedy". “Irresponsible drivers are putting innocent lives at risk. It is obvious that some are refusing to learn, so the only way forward is random and frequent checks, harsh penalties, and highly visible enforcement to deter this reckless behaviour. This country should act to reduce preventable injuries and deaths,” Spiteri said. In a number of proposals to address the issue, the Opposition insisted on “zero tolerance” for accidents caused by drivers who are found to be under the influence of alcohol or drugs, stronger law enforcement, harsher penalties and the introduction of a “new specific criminal offence” for causing death or grievous bodily harm due to gross negligence, recklessness and/or dangerous driving. This offence would carry a minimum penalty of five years’ effective imprisonment, rising up to life imprisonment in cases with aggravating factors, the PN said. Currently, the Police Force has 18 breathalysers, while LESA has five breathalyser kits, all of which only detect alcohol. The PN said the number of road-testing devices “must be increased” and kits that detect drugs should be added. “This is a real and serious problem on our roads,” the PN said. They also highlighted the shortage of staff allocated in the police traffic section and urged for greater investment in the police force, the traffic section and the authorities responsible for road enforcement. These proposals follow a chorus of voices from various entities calling for the introduction of random drug and alcohol tests for motorists and increased road safety.
top_image_caption: The aftermath of Thursday morning's accident in Sliema where the car driver was found to be four times over the alcohol limit. Photo: Michael Spiteri/Facebook

title: Biker seriously injured in Birkirkara crash as police search man who fled scene
subtitle: Uninjured woman in the car treated for shock
content: A motorcyclist was seriously injured in an early morning collision on Friday as police continue to search for a man who was allegedly involved in the accident but ran away from the scene. A 57-year old man from Msida who was riding a Honda motorbike was involved in a collision with a Nissan March at 5.30am on Sir Anthony Mamo street in Birkirkara. The motorcyclist was given medical assistance on site and was later transferred to hospital by ambulance where he was found to have sustained serious injuries. A 25-year old woman from St Paul’s Bay who was in the Nissan was not injured but was taken to hospital suffering from shock.  The police are looking for a man who allegedly was also in the Nissan at the time of the accident but ran away from the scene. It is not clear if he was the driver or a passenger.  Magistrate Monica Borg Galea has launched an inquiry as police continue their investigations.
top_image_caption: A woman who was in the Nissan was treated for shock while a man allegedly also in the car ran away from the scene and is being searched by the police. Photo: Malta Police Force

title: Watch: Parents ‘still in the dark’ on rock fall that killed daughter
subtitle: Magisterial inquiry into 2024 death likely to have been concluded, they say
content: The parents of Mirabelle Falzon, who died last year when she was hit by falling rocks at a popular swimming spot in Marsascala, say they are still in the dark about the exact circumstances of her death. The accident happened on July 19, 2024, when Falzon and her friends were sunbathing in the area of Munxar, beneath the ruins of an 18th-century military battery known as Riħama. Speaking to Times of Malta, Falzon’s parents, Michael and Charmaine, said that while they have heard from government sources that the magisterial inquiry into their daughter’s death has likely been concluded, they are none the wiser as to whether this is true.   Mirabelle’s noisiness was a core part of her character. “She would be in the yard with her boyfriend, and I’d tell her, ‘Does everyone need to know what you’re saying?’ She was always laughing, bringing joy wherever she went. Now the house is silent without her,” Charmaine said. On the one-year anniversary of Mirabelle’s death, her parents organised a mass in her honour. “I can’t thank people enough for coming. The place was packed – everyone still loves her.” Finally, Mirabelle’s father said he had just one request to the authorities. “When someone brings something to your attention, don’t let months and years go by before action is taken. If you save just one life, it’s enough. This is a small country – things shouldn’t fall on deaf ears. No one is infallible and it’s impossible for everything to be perfect, but there are things we could be doing better.” Questions sent to the attorney general’s office regarding the magisterial inquiry remained unanswered at the time of writing.
top_image_caption: Mirabelle was 'loved by everyone'.

title: Over a day later, police still searching for driver who fled Birkirkara crash
subtitle: The Friday morning accident left a motorcyclist with serious injuries
content: Over 24 hours after a collision between a motorcycle and a car left a biker with serious injuries, police are still looking for the car driver who fled the scene of the accident. A 57-year-old man from Msida, who was riding a Honda motorbike, was involved in a collision with a Nissan March at 5.30am on Friday on Sir Anthony Mamo Street in Birkirkara. Police had said that a 25-year old woman, who is now understood to have been the passenger in the Nissan, was taken to hospital in a state of shock. She was otherwise uninjured. However, the male driver of the Nissan allegedly fled the scene of the accident. On Saturday afternoon, police confirmed they are still looking for the man as investigations into the accident continue. Magistrate Monica Borg Galea has launched an inquiry.
top_image_caption: The white Nissan March was involved in a collision with a motorbike in Birkirkara early on Friday morning. The car driver fled the scene and is still on the run. Photos: Malta Police Force

title: 'We spent three terrible years waiting for our dad to die'
subtitle: Paul Scicluna's family recall the pain of seeing him fade away in a vegetative state
content: A sudden cardiac arrest shattered the life of Paul Scicluna, a healthy and happy retired father in 2021. The event plunged him into a vegetative state from which doctors said he would never recover and for three years his family endured a painful vigil, watching him fade away, waiting for him to die. Less than a year after Paul Scicluna’s death, two of his children – Kevin and Marilyn – have decided to open up to advocate for a more inclusive euthanasia law, believing that their father should have had the choice of a dignified end. They told Times of Malta their father would have benefitted from the option, and that the government’s proposed criteria are too narrow to have helped him.  he could have donated his organs, because they were all still working perfectly after the accident,” Marilyn said. “But the principles of the law as proposed by the government wouldn’t even have made our dad eligible for it.” “We’re not saying a euthanasia law should force people to opt for it,” Kevin said. “But if someone is going through something like our situation and they feel like it makes sense to them, then why take it away from them?” Kevin and Marilyn said they, too, would create a living will if given the option, a document that would allow them to specify their wishes for end-of-life care. “That way, at least we know that if we’re ever in a situation like that, we have a living will that can speak for us,” Marilyn said. “My dad didn’t deserve to die like that.”
top_image_caption: Paul with his daughter Marilyn. Family photo

title: ‘It’s torture’: Pembroke crash victim’s mum asks why no charges filed a month on
subtitle: Magistrate Ian Farrugia had been assigned to lead the crash inquiry but resigned earlier this month for personal reasons
content: The mother of a 27-year-old motorcyclist killed in a Pembroke crash has voiced frustration that, one month later, police have not charged the driver involved. In the early hours of July 26, Tenjo Kosev was riding his Honda home to Paola after a gym session when he collided with a BMW 1 Series driven by a 22-year-old.  He worked as a videographer and loved spending time on his computer, riding his motorbike with friends and going to the gym. For the couple, the delay feels like an insult. “This isn’t about revenge. We don’t know who the driver is and don’t care. This is about justice. All other accidents they charge someone so why not in my son’s case?” In response to questions from Times of Malta, police said: “Kindly note that a magisterial inquiry and police investigations are still ongoing, hence it wouldn’t be prudent to comment further at this stage.”
top_image_caption: Tenjo Kosev when he was a child with his mother, Didi Krasteva.

title: Robert Abela announces ongoing revision of drink-drug driving penalties
subtitle: Drink and drug driving have been mentioned in several recent road fatalities.
content: The government is revising penalties for drink and drug driving, Robert Abela said on Sunday. “There is an ongoing exercise to determine if the penalties are sufficient for these sort of crimes. If you ask me, I think there should be a serious revision,” Abela said in a broadcast interview.  “It’s time to have a deterrent... there will be serious penalties. You will be taken to court and will be convicted on the parameters of the penalties  A Wolt courier, Khim Bahadur Pun, died on August 10 after a 17-year-old (who cannot be named by court order) allegedly ploughed into him. The teenager, who is accused of running away from the scene, was also allegedly found to be above the legal limit. On Thursday, a motorist who crashed head-on into a bus on Tower Road in Sliema was four times over the alcohol limit. The man pleaded guilty to driving recklessly while under the influence. That crash had no fatalities. Several emergency doctors have called for stiffer penalties for drink and drug driving, as well as random testing.  The Nationalist Party has said it will be proposing a private member’s bill for “zero tolerance” for accidents caused by drivers who are found to be under the influence of alcohol or drugs. The Insurance Association Malta and the Association of Catering Establishments have also called for random roadside checks and stricter penalties. Magistrate Joe Mifsud called for random roadside alcohol and drug testing of drivers, after a fatal Senglea motorcycle crash revealed the rider had cocaine in his system. Replying to questions by One News editor Josef Caruana on Sunday, Abela said that besides legislation, there will be stricter enforcement by increasing the presence of police, Transport Malta, and LESA officials on the road. He added that there also needed to be more campaigns to deter people from driving while drunk or high.
top_image_caption: 'It’s time to have a deterrent which says that if you were at fault in this way, there will be serious penalties' Abela said. Photo: PL

title: Joslin insists on random testing as PM says drink-drive penalties may be raised
subtitle: 'Protection, not reaction, must be the guiding principle'
content: Emergency doctor Jonathan Joslin on Sunday reiterated his call for random testing of motorists for alcohol and drugs after the prime minister said penalties were being revised, but did not mention roadside testing. At present motorists are only tested after accidents or when there is 'reasonable suspicion' that they may be driving under the influence. "Random Testing is the true deterrent in decreasing injury and death on Malta’s roads," Joslin, leading consultant at the Mater Dei emergency department, wrote in a Facebook post.  "While higher fines and stronger punishments may act as one layer of deterrence, experts insist that the real game-changer lies in random roadside alcohol and drug testing. This must be applied before a collision happens, not only after injury or death has occurred. "Protection, not reaction, must be the guiding principle. Drivers must understand that the risk of being caught under the influence does not depend solely on the tragic aftermath of a crash. It must be clear, publicly and categorically, that anyone can be stopped at any time, tested on the spot, and face serious legal consequences if found guilty," the doctor stressed. He said the prime minister's reform must therefore ensure that random roadside testing for all vehicles becomes the central deterrent.  "Only then will Malta send the strongest possible message: if you drive under the influence, you will be caught – and the consequences will be severe. Several groups have over the past weeks called for roadside random testing after a spate of accidents linked to driving under the influence. Among them were the Insurance Association, the Malta Hotels and Catering Establishments, the Association of Catering Establishments (ACE). The government itself raised the possibility of random drug testing for drivers when it launched the National Drug Policy for public consultation in March last year.
top_image_caption: Jonathan Joslin is leading calls for random testing of motorists for alcohol and drugs.

title: Labour MP Edward Zammit Lewis backs calls for random breath testing
subtitle: Former justice minister joins chorus of voices calling for measure to cut road deaths
content: Labour MP Edward Zammit Lewis has backed calls for the government to introduce random breath testing to reduce road deaths.  The former justice minister joined a growing list of individuals and organisations asking for police to be given the power to test drivers for drugs and alcohol, even if they do not show signs of inebriation.  "Random testing without the need for reasonable suspicion is an effective preventative tool,” Zammit Lewis said.   Pressure has been mounting on the government to introduce random breath testing over the past few weeks, following a spate of serious traffic accidents in which drugs and alcohol were involved.   Zammit Lewis said that the situation on the roads appeared to be worsening, while referring to repeated pleas to the authorities by emergency doctor Jonathan Joslin.    “This despite several projects by Labour governments to greatly improve our country’s infrastructure in an effort to increase safety, especially by my colleague Ian Borg,” he wrote on Facebook.  Zammit Lewis acknowledged that random testing presented an ethical dilemma when it came to protecting people’s right to privacy, but said he believed the proposed change to the law would benefit the common good by increasing road safety and saving lives.  “There are models in countries like the Netherlands, Sweden, France, Germany and Ireland, which have been implemented and are now seen as effective deterrent to fatal traffic accidents.”  The MP said he agreed with Prime Minister Robert Abela, who on Sunday said the government was reviewing drink-driving penalties.  “However, I also agree with the idea of ‘prevention not reaction’," he said. Both the Malta Hotels and Restaurants Association and the Association of Catering Establishments have backed calls for random testing, as has Insurance Association Malta.   The legal amendment has also found support among the judiciary. In a recent inquiry into the death of a motorcyclist who was found to have cocaine in his system, Magistrate Joe Mifsud endorsed a 2023 position paper co-written by NGO Doctors For Road Safety, the Maltese Association of Psychiatry and the Foundation for Welfare Services on drug-driving under the influence of psychoactive drugs.    Mifsud endorsed each of the paper’s eight recommendations, including the introduction of a legal framework to enable random drug testing for psychoactive substances, as well as the random screening of professional drivers, such as taxi, school bus, coach and heavy machinery drivers.  Zammit Lewis has recently used social media to take aim at various government measures.  He criticised the prime minister's planning reforms committee and pushed for the immediate recognition of the state of Palestine.
top_image_caption: Zammit Lewis said Malta should follow in the footsteps of various EU countries in introducing random breath tests on motorists. File photo.

title: Four days on, police still search for man who allegedly fled Birkirkara crash
subtitle: Motorcyclist was seriously injured in crash
content: Police are still searching for a man who allegedly fled the scene of an accident that left a motorcyclist seriously injured four days ago. On Friday, a 57-year-old man who was riding a Honda motorbike was involved in a collision with a Nissan March at 5.30am on Sir Anthony Mamo Street in Birkirkara.  The motorcyclist was taken to the hospital, where he was found to have sustained serious injuries.  At the time, police said a 25-year-old woman was taken to the hospital in a state of shock, but officers were still searching for a man who was allegedly in the car at the time of the accident and fled the scene.  Replying to questions on Monday, police said a magisterial inquiry and police investigations are still ongoing, noting it "wouldn't be prudent to comment further at this stage". After further questioning, a police spokesperson said the male person who was allegedly in the vehicle during the accident has not yet been found.  Magistrate Monica Borg Galea has launched an inquiry. On August 10, a food courier was killed after a hit-and-run in Birkirkara. The 17-year-old driver was arrested hours later after fleeing the scene on foot.
top_image_caption: The motorcyclist was taken to hospital following the collision on Friday morning. Photo: Malta Police Force

title: Six parked cars damaged in Sliema crash
subtitle: No one injured in the early morning accident
content: Six parked cars were damaged when they were hit by another car on Tower Road, Sliema, early on Tuesday. The accident happened at 5.10am when a Renault Megane smashed into a Citroen C4, a Peugeot 308, a Honda Jazz, a Land Rover Evoke, a Kia Picanto and a Smart x 2 on Tower Road, near Independence Gardens. No one was injured, with the motorist reportedly saying the crash was the result of a skid.
top_image_caption: Some of the damaged cars.

title: Chamber of Advocates joins calls for random roadside testing
subtitle: 'Malta should bring itself in line with its European counterparts'
content: The Chamber of Advocates has joined calls for the introduction of random roadside testing to be carried out by the police. It said in a statement it said that it fully supports the calls made Dr Jonathan Joslin, lead consultant at Mater Dei Hospital's emergency department, for the introduction of random roadside testing to be carried out. Joslin has insisted that random testing would be a more effective deterrent to prevent serious traffic accidents than the reactive imposition of higher penalties to those who cause such crashes. The Chamber said Malta should bring itself in line with its European counterparts by introducing oral fluid roadside testing and by granting the police the authority to stop and test drivers at random. At present, Maltese law does not permit the use of oral fluid roadside testing — a procedure already adopted in several European countries.  Roadside testing is only carried out when there is 'reasonable suspicion' that a motorist might be driving under the influence.  "The Chamber of Advocates believes that this measure constitutes the only genuine deterrent capable of reducing fatalities and injuries on Maltese road," the advocates said.
top_image_caption: The Chamber of Advocates has called for random testing of motorists. File photo.

title: Random drug, alcohol testing to be introduced; mandatory prison for fatalities
subtitle: Plan to introduce roadside tests and harshen punishment for drivers
content: The government is planning to introduce random drug and alcohol testing on the roads and to ensure anyone who kills someone under the influence cannot get a suspended sentence, but is sent to prison. Prime Minister Robert Abela and Home Affairs Minister Byron Camilleri announced the details of a new law that has been tabled in parliament in the wake of pressure from several professionals following a spate of horrifying road accidents this summer. The proposed changes, which Camilleri said come as police road checks have surged to unprecedented levels, focus on strengthening penalties and introducing new testing methods. If the law is approved, police will be empowered to conduct drug tests on drivers at the roadside, similar to current alcohol checks. Drug and alcohol tests can be performed on drivers even without reasonable suspicion. Moreover, anyone who causes a person's death while under the influence of alcohol or drugs will face a mandatory prison sentence, eliminating the option of a suspended sentence. And fines for driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs will be increased. Police will also be able to request the immediate suspension of a driver's license while court proceedings are pending. At present motorists are only tested after accidents or when there is 'reasonable suspicion' that they may be driving under the influence.  Emergency doctor Jonathan Joslin on Sunday reiterated his call for random testing of motorists for alcohol and drugs, saying it is the true deterrent in decreasing injury and death. Several groups have over the past weeks called for roadside random testing after a spate of accidents linked to driving under the influence. Among them were the Insurance Association, the Malta Hotels and Catering Establishments, the Association of Catering Establishments (ACE). The government itself raised the possibility of random drug testing for drivers when it launched the National Drug Policy for public consultation in March last year. The Nationalist Party had said it would bring in a private member's bill to try to reduce road deaths.
top_image_caption: At present motorists are only tested after accidents or when there is 'reasonable suspicion' that they may be driving under the influence. Photo: Shutterstock

title: Emergency doctor hails introduction of random drink-driving roadside tests
subtitle: "Reason prevails", emergency doctor Jonathan Joslin said after his repeated calls for random testing were finally heard
content: The emergency doctor who has been calling for random testing of motorists for alcohol and drugs praised the government’s decision to introduce such random tests.  “Reason prevails: Random roadside testing leads the way,” emergency doctor Jonathan Joslin said in a Facebook post on Tuesday, shortly after the government announced several proposals to curb drink-drug driving.  “The adoption of random roadside testing marks a decisive step towards safer roads. By deterring dangerous behaviours such as drink and drug driving, it ensures greater accountability among drivers and creates a stronger culture of responsibility on our roads,” Joslin said.  Joslin was at the forefront insisting that random testing would be a more effective deterrent to prevent serious traffic accidents than the reactive imposition of higher penalties to those who cause such crashes. His comments come after Prime Minister Robert Abela and Home Affairs Minister Byron Camilleri announced the proposed changes, in the wake of pressure from several professionals and lobby groups following a spate of horrifying road accidents this summer.  They will be incorporated into a bill tabled in parliament last June, titled Traffic Regulation Ordinance (Amendment) Bill, which will be debated once parliament resumes in September. Only the bill's title was tabled at the time.  If the bill is approved, police will be empowered to conduct drug tests on drivers at the roadside, similar to current alcohol checks. Fines for driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs will also be increased.  Moreover, anyone who causes a person's death while under the influence of alcohol or drugs will face a mandatory prison sentence, eliminating the option of a suspended sentence. Along with Joslin, the Insurance Association Malta also welcomed the government's move to introduce harsher penalties for drunk and drugged driving. The IAM said it has been actively lobbying for such measures over recent years, as it firmly believes tougher enforcement will serve as a much-needed deterrent against irresponsible and dangerous conduct on the roads. “These measures send a clear signal to all that protecting the lives of responsible, law-abiding road users is paramount,” IAM director General Adrian Galea said. The Association said the reform represents an important step forward in safeguarding lives.
top_image_caption: An AFM solider is being charged for driving under the influence in a fatal car crash last month. Photo: Malta Police Force

title: Man dies after electric shock while working near Golden Bay
subtitle: The 41-year-old was electrocuted while working on an electricity pole
content: A 41-year-old man has died after suffering an electric shock while working on an electricity pole. The accident happened in Triq Palma, near Golden Bay at about 12.30pm on Wednesday. The man fell into a ditch as a result of the accident. He was assisted by rescuers of the Civil Protection Department and an ambulance crew, but died in hospital. Magistrate Joe Mifsud is holding an inquiry. The police and the Occupational Health and Safety Authority are investigating.
top_image_caption: The scene of the tragic incident. Photo: Matthew Mirabelli

title: Roadside testing could create injustice for thousands of cannabis users: Releaf
subtitle: 'Presence of drugs in saliva does not mean impairment' - NGO
content: A cannabis association slammed the government's decision to introduce random roadside alcohol and drug testing, claiming it can create "injustice" for thousands of cannabis users.  While the decision to introduce tougher drink and drug laws was welcomed by the opposition and industry stakeholders, Releaf Malta didn't share the same sentiment.  "Releaf Malta has been requesting a meeting for six months, but we always find doors shut in our faces," Releaf Malta president Andrew Bonello said in a reel on Tuesday evening.  "The amendments introducing roadside testing for cannabis without an 'impairment assessment' will create injustice for over 60,000 cannabis users. We remind that the presence of drugs in saliva does not mean impairment or that the person is dangerous."  Prime Minister Robert Abela and Home Affairs Minister Byron Camilleri announced the proposed changes on Tuesday, in the wake of pressure from several professionals and lobby groups following a spate of horrifying road accidents this summer. The proposed changes, which Camilleri said come as police road checks have surged to unprecedented levels, focus on strengthening penalties and introducing new testing methods. Camilleri did not clarify what drugs would be tested.  Bonello said cannabis can be detected hours after last use, but he argued it does not mean the person is dangerous and unable to drive.  He said breathalysers work differently and indicate when a driver is not in a fit state to drive. "Dialogue with us as you do with insurance companies and lawyers who have an economic interest in these measures passing. We remind that across Europe there are hundreds of court cases challenging unfair technologies like these," Bonello said. Malta became the first EU country to legalise recreational cannabis use in 2021. Under current legislation, adults are allowed to possess up to seven grams of cannabis and grow up to four plants at home. Consumption remains limited to private spaces and is prohibited in public or near minors.
top_image_caption: Releaf Malta disagrees with the introduction of random drug roadside testing, claiming it will create injustice for cannabis users. Photo: Shutterstock

title: Motorcyclist grievously injured in Żebbuġ crash
subtitle: Accident happened on Tuesday evening
content: A motorcyclist was grievously injured after he was involved in a collision with a car in Żebbuġ on Tuesday evening. The accident happened at 6.30pm on Attard Road, in Żebbuġ when a 28-year old motorcyclist from Siġġiewi riding a Benelli motorbike was involved in a collision with a Peugeot 2008 driven by a 32-year old man from Balzan. The motorcyclist was taken to Mater Dei hospital by ambulance where he was certified to have sustained grievous injuries. Police investigations are underway.
top_image_caption: The aftermath of the accident in Żebbuġ. Photo: Malta Police Force

title: Drunk driver in Baħar iċ-Ċagħaq crash pleads guilty to most charges
subtitle: Woman denies reckless driving in accident that left motorcyclist critically injured
content: A woman involved in a Baħar ic-Cagħaq collision that left a motorcyclist seriously injured has pleaded guilty on most of the charges, except that of reckless driving. Yoana Valentinova Gatt, a 44-year-old Bulgarian national living in St Paul’s Bay, stands accused of causing grievous bodily harm through negligence, reckless driving, damaging the victim’s motorcycle, driving under the influence and drink driving.  She is pleading guilty to four out of five charges. A breathalyser test had revealed she was six times over the legal limit, with the test marking 124.9 μg/100ml (microgrammes of alcohol per 100ml breath). On Wednesday morning, police inspector Nathan Bugejatold the court the police were informed about a collision between a car and a motorcycle just before the exit to the roundabout at about 3:37pm. Initially, the motorcyclist was certified as being in danger of dying. CCTV footage captured the whole accident as it happened. “The motorcycle was at the stop sign on the give way, when Gatt ran over it,” Bugeja told the court. Fiott asked whether her client had been speeding, and Bugeja said that while he could not calculate the speed from watching the CCTV footage, “it did not show any large amounts of speed”. The court is still in session. More details to follow.
top_image_caption: Yoana Valentinova Gatt (inset) is pleading guilty to four out of five charges in the Baħar iċ-Ċagħaq accident. File photo.

title: Random roadside drugs and alcohol testing 'significant step forward'
subtitle: Measures 'essential' for Malta's reputation as a safe tourism destination
content: The Malta Hotels and Restaurants Association on Wednesday “strongly supported” random roadside testing for drugs and alcohol saying it will have a positive impact on Malta's reputation as a safe tourism destination. The association said the introduction of random roadside testing is a “significant step forward” in addressing reckless behaviour on the roads and protecting lives. “These measures are not only essential for upholding the rule of law but also for reinforcing Malta’s international reputation as a safe and welcoming destination,” the MHRA said. Prime Minister Robert Abela and Home Affairs Minister Byron Camilleri announced on Tuesday announced that police will be given the power to randomly test drivers for alcohol or drugs while laws will be revised to ensure anyone involved in fatal crashes while driving under the influence is sent to prison.   Recognising that safety and security are “decisive success factors” for Malta as a “quality tourism destination”, the MHRA said tourists and residents must feel assured that Malta provides a safe and orderly environment, free from risks that undermine wellbeing and public trust. The association stressed that better sustainable tourism management is “inseparable” from responsible enforcement and strong deterrents against behaviour that endanger society. “These reforms will help ensure a higher standard of living for residents and the local community, while delivering outstanding, safe experiences for even the most discerning tourists,” the MHRA added.
top_image_caption: The MHRA says it "strongly supports" the introduction of random roadside testing for drugs and alcohol as it will make Malta safer not just for residents for also for tourists. File photo: Shutterstock

title: GWU backs tougher sentences for drug and alcohol driving, urges more testing
subtitle: Union 'strongly endorses' proposals
content: The General Workers’ Union (GWU) has backed recent proposals for tougher sentences on drivers caught driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs. The union also called for more frequent random testing of motorists, which it said, together with tougher penalties, would improve road safety and discipline. The statement follows the announcement of a proposed bill earlier this week, empowering police to carry out random drug and alcohol testing of motorists without the need for prior suspicion. The proposals, unveiled Tuesday by Prime Minister Robert Abela and Home Affairs Minister Byron Camilleri, will also see motorists who cause a person’s death while driving under the influence handed a mandatory prison sentence. In a statement, the GWU said it “strongly endorses” the proposals for tougher sentences, with union general secretary Josef Bugeja saying it was “neither appropriate nor fair for someone to lose their life due to the reckless actions of others”. “We have witnessed too many accidental deaths on our roads, often caused by individuals under the influence of alcohol or drugs at the time of the incident”, he said. “It is essential to foster a culture of discipline in our country and implement strong reforms to create more deterrents for those who drive irresponsibly. Such individuals pose a danger not only to themselves but also to others, and their actions can tragically lead to loss of life.” Bugeja also highlighted the need for “increased roadblocks at various times” to conduct random testing of motorists, as part of efforts to enhance safety on the roads. The recent proposals were welcomed by the PN, emergency doctor Jonathan Joslin – who has repeatedly called for random testing of motorists – Doctors for Road Safety and the Malta Hotels and Restaurants Association. The announcement came in the wake of a spate of horrifying road accidents this summer. Police caught four drunk drivers during roadside inspections carried out overnight between Tuesday and Wednesday in Żebbuġ, Marsa, Msida, and St Julian’s.
top_image_caption: The GWU stressed the need for more discipline on the roads. Photo: Shutterstock.

title: Man killed by electric shock identified as Charles Mifsud
subtitle: Former hawker remembered by Żebbuġ residents as a ‘true gentleman’
content: A man who died by electric shock on Wednesday near Golden Bay has been identified as Charles Mifsud. Mifsud, 41, was a resident of Żebbuġ. He died after being electrocuted while working on an electricity pole, falling into a ditch as a result of the accident. It remains unclear what Mifsud was working on at the time of his death. It is also not yet known whether he was self-employed or working for a company. Until a few years ago, he was a fruit and vegetable vendor in Żebbuġ and was well-known in the community. Residents of Żebbuġ took to social media on Thursday to express their "shock" and condolences, with people stating that he was a "true gentleman”. The accident occurred at around 12.30pm on Wednesday in Triq Palma, near Golden Bay. He was assisted by rescuers from the Civil Protection Department and an ambulance crew but died later in hospital. Magistrate Joe Mifsud is leading an inquiry. Police and the Occupational Health and Safety Authority are investigating. Four people died in workplace accidents during the first six months of the year, while 1,041 non-fatal accidents were recorded, according to data released by the National Statistics Office.
top_image_caption: Charles Mifsud and his wife. Photo: Facebook.

title: Case continues of drunk driver in Baħar iċ-Ċagħaq crash, driver granted bail
subtitle: Yoana Valentinova Gatt has admitted to drink driving but denies reckless driving charge
content: A woman involved in a Baħar ic-Cagħaq collision that left a motorcyclist seriously injured has been granted bail. Yoana Valentinova Gatt, a 44-year-old Bulgarian national living in St Paul’s Bay, admitted earlier this week to causing grievous bodily harm through negligence to the motorcyclist, damaging the victim’s motorcycle, driving under the influence and drink driving. She denies the reckless driving charge, and the case continues with respect to that charge. The incident took place on August 17 when Valentinova Gatt hit the motorcycle from the rear, injuring its driver, a 53-year-old Belgian national living in Gżira. Eyewitnesses who testified earlier this week explained how five men had lifted the woman’s car, which had its engine still running, to free the trapped motorcyclist. The motorcyclist was placed in the recovery position until the emergency services arrived at the scene. A breathalyser test revealed Valentinova Gatt was six times over the legal limit, with the test marking 124.9 μg/100ml (microgrammes of alcohol per 100ml breath). On Friday morning, the court granted the woman bail against a €2,000 deposit and a €10,000 personal guarantee. She was ordered to sign the bail book twice a week. Magistrate Antoine Agius Bonnici presided. Police inspector Nathan Bugeja prosecuted. Legal aid lawyer Nadya Fiott appeared for the accused.
top_image_caption: Bulgarian national Yoana Valentinova Gatt was six times over the legal limit at the time of the crash. File photo.

title: Skip and run: truck smashes Rabat balcony and flees
subtitle: Second time in a decade that a truck has crashed into the same Rabat home
content: A truck hit the balcony of a Rabat home and kept going without stopping - and the property owner says it is the second time a truck has damaged the house. The balcony subsequently had to be dismantled as it was deemed unsafe following the impact.  Cyril Spiteri Staines and his wife received a call from "shocked" neighbours just after 9pm on Wednesday, who told them a truck had hit their Rabat property and kept going.  Neighbours told them they saw the vehicle responsible but did not note its number plate as it was too dark to see.  “I am more angry than shocked. This savage just breaks our property and drives off like nothing happened,” said Spiteri Staines, 53. Neighbours described the truck as a skiploader without a skip on the back.  The couple live in St Julian's and the Rabat property is currently unoccupied.   Police and Civil Protection Department officials arrived on site shortly after being informed. A report was filed and, after assessing the damage, authorities decided the balcony was too dangerous to leave standing. It was pulled down shortly afterwards. “I tip my hat to the authorities; they did an outstanding job on our end,” said Spiteri Staines.    “Unbelievably, this isn’t even the first time that our house was hit by a truck,” he added. Spiteri Staines explained that around a decade ago, the same house, but on the side facing Triq Tal-Virtù, was damaged when a truck carrying animal feed crashed into it. That time, the driver took responsibility. He said he hoped the outcome this time would be the same. “If the person who crashed into our place was in any way a responsible person, they would have stopped to assess the damage and take accountability, but they didn’t. So now we want them caught and for them to fix the damage.” He is appealing to anyone who may have witnessed the incident or has CCTV footage to contact him at cspiteristaines@gmail.com.
top_image_caption: The damage to the balcony on the night of the hit, from one of the neighbors POV Photo: Spiteri Staines

title: Motorcyclist grievously injured in Marsa crash
subtitle: Accident happened on Triq Emmanuele Luigi Galizia
content: A motorcyclist was grievously injured on Friday afternoon after he was involved in a collision with a car in Marsa. The accident happened at around 3.15pm in Triq Emmanuele Luigi Galizia. The 55-year old man who is from Birżebbuġa was riding his Daelim motorbike when he was involved in a collision with a BMW 318 driven by a 33-year old woman from Luqa. A 74-year old man also from Luqa was a passenger in the car. The motorcyclist was given first aid on site before being transferred to Mater Dei Hospital where he was found to have sustained grievous injuries. Police investigations are under way.
top_image_caption: The accident happened on Triq Emmanuele Luigi Galizia in Marsa. Photo: Malta Police Force

title: 87-year-old woman injured after being run over in Qormi
content:
Tista' taqra bil- Malti.
An 87-year-old woman from Qormi was hospitalised today after she was run over in Qormi this morning.
The incident occurred at approximately 7:30am on Triq l-Imdina, Qormi. Initial police investigations indicate that the woman was hit by a vehicle driven by a 68-year-old man, also a resident of Qormi.
A medical team attended to the woman at the scene before she was transported to the hospital by ambulance. She has been certified as having sustained grievous injuries.
Police investigations are ongoing.
A previous version of this article incorrectly stated the location of the accident. The police have since clarified that the incident occurred on Triq l-Imdina, Qormi, and not Vjal il-Kottoner, Fgura. We apologise for this error.

title: Maltese couple killed in Sicily head-on collision with truck
subtitle: Maltese 'senior citizens' pronounced dead after crash on Catania-Ragusa motorway
content: An elderly Maltese couple were killed in a car accident on a Sicily motorway on Wednesday.  Sources confirmed the husband, aged 73, and his 69-year old wife were driving a Toyota Yaris with a Maltese registration number plate on the Catania – Ragusa motorway close to Lentini when they were involved in a head-on collision with a truck at 3pm. Local radio station Radio Una Voce Vicina reported that emergency services from Augusta, the fire brigade and a helicopter ambulance were called on site.  The couple were extracted from the car but medical officers confirmed they had been killed on impact, reports said. The bodies were transferred to the mortuary at Lentini hospital.   The motorway was closed in both directions for several hours during the investigation. Both vehicles were taken away as part of the investigations at the request of authorities in Siracusa.  More to follow.
top_image_caption: The accident happened at around 3pm on Wednesday. Photo: Radio Una Voce Vicina

title: Maltese couple killed in Sicily crash named as Doris and Manuel Buhagiar
subtitle: Malta Police Union lead tribute to former policeman and his wife
content: Tributes have started pouring in for the Maltese couple who lost their lives in a car accident in Sicily on Wednesday. Former police officer PC 574 Manuel Buhagiar, 73, and his wife Doris, 69, from Żebbuġ died on impact when their Malta-registered Toyota Yaris was involved in a head on collision with a truck on the Catania - Ragusa state road near the exit to Lentini. In a Facebook post on Wednesday evening, the Malta Police Union extended its "heartfelt condolences" to the family.  A relative, Jenny Barbara Buhagiar, expressed her "shock" at the unexpected news. "Cannot believe it! It was already sad enough when the news came out without any names, but just foudn out who they are and Manuel was my father's cousin. What an unexpected shock tonight," she wrote on Facebook. In a brief statement, the Foreign Ministry said it was in close contact with the family  and assisting them.
top_image_caption: Manuel and his wife Doris Buhagiar were killed in a car crash in Sicily. Photo: Facebook

title: Two injured following Gżira traffic accident
subtitle: A motorcyclist was seriously injured following the Thursday accident
content: Two men were injured on Thursday afternoon following a traffic accident on Gżira front.  The police were informed of the accident at around 6.15pm in Triq ix-Xatt, when a 24-year-old moped driver, from Tarxien, riding a Surron Light Bee, was involved in a collision with a Honda NSC110 driven by a 35-year-old Libyan from Żurrieq.  A medical team was called to the scene, and both men were rushed to Mater Dei Hospital.  Later, the 35-year-old man was certified to have sustained serious injuries. The other driver was certified as slightly injured. Police investigations are still ongoing.
top_image_caption: The traffic accident took place at Triq ix-Xatt on Thursday late afternoon. Photo: Malta Police Force

title: Watch: Mildred’s last selfie of joy before death struck
subtitle: Family of crash victim recount the night that changed their lives
content: Less than an hour before she was fatally struck by a car, Mildred Azzopardi shared a final snapshot of the simple joys she cherished most: tea and cheesecakes by the sea with her husband. At 9.10pm, the 62-year-old mother posted a selfie in the family WhatsApp group, ‘The Fam’, captioned in Maltese: “bela te u pastizzi tal-Serkin u ħallieh ħa jħabbat” (a cup of tea and Serkin cheesecakes and let it roll), signing off with an angel emoji. By 9.45pm, tragedy had struck. “She sent it with a smiley of an angel – thankfully, we all saw it,” recalled her children Cain, 35, Janice, 32, Amy, 26, and Maria, 22. Speaking for the first time since the accident that claimed their mother’s life and left their father still in hospital, the siblings described how the crash turned their world upside down in an instant.  “Every night when we were little. she would tell us good night and remind us: ‘You are not alone’. As kids, it gave us the chills. And she was right – we are not alone. The support has been overwhelming. At least we have one another. When one of us breaks down, the others help,” they say.

title: Motorcyclist seriously injured in Luqa crash
subtitle: The accident took place at 1.30pm in Triq l-Ewwel Titjira
content: A motorcyclist was rushed to the hospital on Sunday afternoon after a crash in Luqa.  The police said the accident happened at around 1.30pm in Triq l-Ewwel Titjira. According to investigations, a Citroen DS3 driven by a 35-year-old man, a Żurrieq resident, and a Hyosung XRX driven by a 62-year-old man were involved in the accident.  A medical team was called to the scene, and the motorcyclist was taken to Mater Dei Hospital via ambulance. He was later certified as having suffered serious injuries.  Police investigations are ongoing.
top_image_caption: The accident happened on Sunday afternoon. Photo: Health Ministry

title: Minimum three years’ jail for drunk, drugged drivers guilty of manslaughter
subtitle: The judiciary cannot provide a lesser punishment, says draft legislation soon to be debated in parliament
